to recover the reasonable costs of actions deemed necessary to bring about compliance herewith. (Ord. 1152 § 5, 2008)
Title 7
RESERVED
Title 8
HEALTH AND SAFETY
Chapter 8.04
NUISANCES GENERALLY
8.04.010: DESIGNATED; ACTIONS AGAINST PERSON CREATING:
A. Anything which is injurious to the health or morals of another, or offensive to the senses or an obstruction to the free use of property so as to interfere
with a reasonable person in the comfortable enjoyment of life or property is declared a nuisance and may be the subject of an action.
B. In the case of a moral or public nuisance, an action may be brought by any resident citizen of the city or by the city itself; in all other cases the action
may be brought by any person whose personal enjoyment is injuriously affected, or whose personal enjoyment is lessened by the nuisance; and by
the judgment the nuisance may be enjoined or abated, as well as damages recovered. The costs of abatement are as determined by Idaho Code
sections 50-334 and 50-1008. (Ord. 513 § 1, 1986: prior code § 6-1-34)
8.04.020: CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITY PROHIBITED DURING CERTAIN HOURS:
It is unlawful and is deemed a public nuisance for any person to engage in acts of building construction, site development, use of heavy equipment for
earthmoving or installation of public works, or other construction activities which involve use of concussion, compression, power tools, or which produce
bothersome noise, illumination, dust, or similar undesirable environmental effects onto adjoining residential properties, between the hours of ten o'clock
(10:00) P.M. on one day and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on the succeeding day of the week. (Ord. 648 § 1, 1992)
8.04.030: EXCEPTION; SPECIAL CONDITIONS:
A. Any person desiring to carry out construction work or other development activities which would violate the terms of section 8.04.020 of this chapter
may petition the city clerk for an exemption from the limitations contained therein. Such exemption may be granted by the city administrator, upon
payment of the appropriate fee established by resolution of the city council, and upon approval of a verified application for exception showing that:
1. The construction or land development activity will take placein an area exclusively committed to commercial or industrial land use and that the
activity prohibited by section 8.04.020 of this chapter would not produce conflicts with the peace and quiet of residential or temporary lodging uses
in the vicinity; or
2. The construction or land development activity will take place in an essentially undeveloped area and that no residences or other lodging uses
would be affected by construction activity carried on during the hours proscribed in section 8.04.020 of this chapter; or
3. Some other factor(s) unique to the site preclude the possibility of conflict with adjoining land uses intended to be protected by the provisions of this
chapter;
4. The project must operate in violation of the express provisions of section 8.04.020 of this chapter in order to be completed (e.g., continuous
concrete pour);
5. An emergency exists which precludes compliance if emergency conditions are to be alleviated.
B. It shall be the responsibility of the person requesting an exemption from the provisions of section 8.04.020 of this chapter to present sufficient
competent evidence to show compliance with the provisions of this section. The city administrator may approve, conditionally approve, or reject a
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 61/268
request for exemption based upon the application submitted and any investigation he conducts. The reasons for conditional approval or rejection
shall be contained in writing in the response provided by the administrator.
C. Any exemption request which has been approved or conditionally approved may be revoked upon receipt of a complaint by the city administrator or
his designee. Any revocation shall be effective upon mailing to the person exempted. Revocation or denial of an exemption may be appealed to the
city council, with mailed notice to be provided to any complaining parties and to owners of adjoining lands. (Ord. 648 § 1, 1992)
8.04.040: ENFORCEMENT; VIOLATIONS:
Any violation of section 8.04.020 of this chapter or the terms of any exemption or conditional exemption shall be punishable as a violation of this code in
accordance with chapter 1.24 of this code. In addition, the city may elect to bring legal action in a court of competent jurisdiction to enforce the
requirements of this chapter by seeking a court order to prevent further violation. (Ord. 648 § 1, 1992)
Chapter 8.08
FIREWORKS AND FIRE PREVENTION
8.08.010: AUTHORIZATION:
This title is enacted pursuant to the general police power and the authority granted to cities by article 12, section 2 of the Idaho constitution and Idaho
Code title 39, chapter 26. (Ord. 959 § 2, 2000)
8.08.020: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
The purpose of this title is to promote the public health, safety and the general welfare of the residents of the city by reducing the risk of wildfire and to
foster the safe sale and use of fireworks within the city. (Ord. 1296, 2016)
8.08.030: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this title, words, terms, and phrases, and their derivations shall have the meanings given below or as ascribed to them in title 39, chapter
26 of the Idaho Code or as otherwise appropriate to their context.
NATURAL AREA: A naturally vegetated area within a public park that is not irrigated, or manicured.
PUBLIC PARK: Includes any park, natural area, beach, recreation area, trail, playground or play field owned, leased or maintained by the city or school
district 273.
PUBLIC PROPERTY: Includes public parks, public rights of way and streets, curbs and sidewalks, parking lots, alleys and the grounds of public
buildings and schools owned, leased or maintained by the city or school district 273. (Ord. 1296, 2016)
8.08.040: FIREWORKS; REGULATION OF SALES, USE, STORAGE AND DISCHARGE:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person to offer for sale, sell, possess, store, discharge or use fireworks as defined in Idaho Code title 39, chapter 26
except in compliance with the requirements of this chapter and requirements of Idaho Code title 39, chapter 26, or its successor.
B. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, possess or use any of the following dangerous fireworks at any time within the city:
1. Firecrackers, cannon crackers, giant crackers, salutes, silver tube salutes, cherry bombs, mines, ground bombardment, grasshoppers and other
explosive articles of similar nature;
2. Skyrockets and rockets, including all similar devices employing any combustible or explosive material and which rise in the air during discharge;
3. Roman candles, including all devices which discharge balls of fire into the air;
4. Chasers and whistles, including all devices which dart or travel about the surface of the ground during discharge;
5. Snakes and hats containing bichloride of mercury;
6. Sparklers more than ten inches (10") in length or one-fourth inch (1/4") in diameter or made with other than iron wires;
7. All articles for pyrotechnic display such as aerial shells, salutes, flash shells, sky battles, parachute shells, mines, dago bombs and similar devices;
8. All torpedoes which explode by means of friction, or which contain arsenic, and all other similar fireworks devices including cracker balls;
9. Fire balloons, lanterns or balloons of any type which have burning material of any kind attached thereto.
C. It shall be unlawful to use, possess, or in any way prepare to use, any fireworks described in this chapter or Idaho Code within the boundaries of any
public park or property within the city except when permitted by the city as part of an authorized public display. (Ord. 1296, 2016)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 62/268
8.08.050: FIREWORKS; PERMIT REQUIRED:
A. No person, without having a valid fireworks permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this code, shall import, export, possess for purpose of sale,
offer for sale, or sell any fireworks for any use or purpose including agricultural purposes or wildlife control, make a public display of fireworks within
the city or transport fireworks in violation of state or federal law. Sales and use of fireworks shall not contravene the provisions of Idaho Code with
respect to the permitted time and type fireworks to be used.
B. A temporary fireworks sales permit may be issued only to a nonprofit, charitable, religious or eleemosynary corporation or association organized and
existing primarily for veterans', patriotic, charitable or civic betterment purposes. Such corporation or association must be based in Post Falls by
virtue of having its principal and permanent meeting place in the city, must have twenty (20) or more bona fide members and must have been
established for at least two (2) or more years.
C. Applicants desiring to sell nonaerial common fireworks as defined in state law for the time period allowed by state law must first obtain an
administrative permit from the city as required by this code and approval by the Kootenai County fire and rescue as authorized by state law and the
fire code. Evidence of the possession of any such required permit must be demonstrated by the stand owner or operator on request by officials of the
city or the Kootenai County fire and rescue.
D. Both nonaerial common fireworks sales and fireworks displays shall comply with the terms of issued permits and with provisions of this code and
state law. Failure to so comply shall constitute a violation of this code. (Ord. 1296, 2016)
8.08.060: FIRE, BURNING AND SMOKING RESTRICTIONS ON PUBLIC PROPERTY:
A. It is unlawful to make, use or have any open fires in or on any public property unless an official sign is posted on the park, natural area, play field or
other area allowing an open fire. If open fires are allowed, the person burning or making the fire must comply with all fire and burning regulations of
the park, natural area, play field or other area.
B. Smoking and all other activities capable of generating an open flame are prohibited in all city owned, leased and maintained natural areas except at
signed smoking areas. (Ord. 1296, 2016)
8.08.070: OPEN BURNING BANNED UNDER STAGE 2 FIRE RESTRICTIONS:
All burning is prohibited within the city limits of Post Falls for the duration of any stage 2 fire restriction order issued by the Idaho department of lands for
any portion of Kootenai County. The prohibition contained in this section does not apply to the appropriate use of outdoor gas firepits or fireplaces,
covered gas or charcoal barbecue grills or smokers provided that the area surrounding the fireplace, firepit, grill or smoker is kept clear of dry vegetation
or other flammable material and the firepit, fireplace, grill or smoker is monitored by a responsible adult. (Ord. 1296, 2016)
8.08.080: VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES:
A. It shall be a violation of the law to fail to comply with any provision of this chapter, that is, to do that which is described as unlawful or to violate the
requirements established by this chapter or to fail to comply with any lawful order of the planning and building director, any police officer or the fire
marshal.
B. Except as provided in subsection C of this section, any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor
and may be punished as provided in title 1, chapter 1.24 of this code.
C. An initial violation of subsection 8.08.040C of this chapter by possessing fireworks within a public park or property is an infraction punishable by a fine
not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00). Any additional violations of subsection 8.08.040C of this chapter by possessing fireworks within a
public park or property is a misdemeanor punishable as provided in title 1, chapter 1.24 of this code.
D. The city may undertake civil legal action in a court of competent jurisdiction to seek to enjoin conduct which violates the provisions of this chapter
and/or to recover the reasonable costs of actions deemed necessary to bring about compliance herewith. (Ord. 1296, 2016)
Chapter 8.12
EXPLOSIVES
8.12.010: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
This chapter applies to all explosives except small arms ammunition and pyrotechnic devices. (Prior code § 7-3-1)
8.12.020: MANUFACTURE OR STORAGE PROHIBITED; PERMIT REQUIRED TO TRANSPORT:
The manufacture or storage of explosives within the limits of the municipality is prohibited. A permit shall be obtained from the clerk to transport any
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 63/268
explosives in or through the municipality. (Prior code § 7-3-2)
8.12.030: TRANSPORTATION RESTRICTIONS:
A. It is unlawful for any person in charge of a vehicle containing explosives to smoke in, upon or near such vehicle; to drive, load or unload the vehicle
while intoxicated; to drive the vehicle in a careless or reckless manner, or to unload or load such vehicle in a careless or reckless manner.
B. It is unlawful to operate any vehicle containing explosives on any street in the municipality except in compliance with the following rules:
1. No such vehicle shall be so operated unless it is marked, loaded and equipped in full compliance with all laws of the state relating thereto.
2. No trailer shall be used for the conveyance of explosives in the municipality; but semitrailers as defined by statute may be so used.
3. No vehicle carrying explosives shall be parked or permitted to stand anywhere in the municipality longer than is necessary to make a lawful
delivery; provided, that the standing of such vehicle made necessary by mechanical trouble, traffic conditions, accident or in obedience to the
direction of a police officer or traffic signals shall not be considered a violation of this section. (Prior code § 7-3-3)
Chapter 8.16
TRAILER COURTS
8.16.010: DEFINITIONS:
DEPENDENT TRAILER COACH: A trailer coach which does not have a water closet and a bathtub or shower.
INDEPENDENT TRAILER COACH: A trailer coach that does have a water closet and a bathtub or shower.
LOCAL ADMINISTRATIVE AUTHORITIES: The individual official(s), board, department or agency established and authorized by a state, county, city or
other political subdivision created by law to administer and enforce the provisions of the local codes and laws as adopted or amended.
SERVICE BUILDING: A building housing communal toilet, laundry and other sanitary facilities necessary for the health and convenience of the trailer
occupants.
TRAILER COACH: A vehicle without means of self-propulsion, but licensable as a conveyance on public streets or highways, and which is constructed
to permit occupancy as a dwelling or sleeping place for one or more persons.
TRAILER COACH SPACE: A plot of ground within a trailer court designated for the accommodation of one trailer coach.
TRAILER COURT: Any plot of ground upon which two (2) or more occupied trailer coaches are located. (Prior code § 5-3-1)
8.16.020: LOCATION:
A. The site must not be:
1. Close to swamps or other potential breeding places for insects or rodents;
2. Subject to flooding, fire or safety hazards;
3. Exposed to chronic nuisances, such as noise, smoke, fumes and odors.
B. The site should be bounded on at least one side by a public street or highway. (Prior code § 5-3-2(A))
8.16.030: TOPOGRAPHY REQUIREMENTS:
The topography must be favorable to good site drainage, minimum grading, trailer placement and ease of maintenance. Initial site grades exceeding
eight percent (8%), or rock formation close to the surface, are likely to cause high development costs. Sparsely wooded sites providing shade trees are
often advantageous. (Prior code § 5-3-2(B))
8.16.040: UTILITY AVAILABILITY:
The site must be readily accessible to public utilities, including water, sewerage and electricity. (Prior code § 5-3-2(C))
8.16.050: AREA REQUIRED:
The area of the trailer court must be sufficient in size to accommodate:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 64/268
A. The number of trailer coach spaces desired;
B. Roads and parking areas for motor vehicles;
C. Service areas, buildings and playgrounds;
D. On site utilities where public utilities are not available. (Prior code § 5-3-2(D))
8.16.060: IMPROVEMENTS:
The physical improvements of the site must be arranged to provide:
A. A convenient means of pedestrian and vehicular access to each trailer coach space, parking areas and accessory buildings;
B. An adequate supply of potable water;
C. A safe method of sewage disposal;
D. Electrical service for lighting and power; and
E. Diversion of surface water away from buildings, trailer coach spaces, service and recreational areas and its disposal from the site. (Prior code § 5-3-
3)
8.16.070: PLAN REQUIRED:
A plan of the proposed trailer court must be developed for approval of the city building inspector and the board of adjustment, indicating the layout of
trailer coach spaces, roads, walks, service buildings, service areas, utilities and necessary grading. (Prior code § 5-3-4)
8.16.080: NUMBER DETERMINATION:
Determination must be made in the initial planning stage on the number of dependent and independent trailer coaches to be accommodated. (Prior code
§ 5-3-4)
8.16.090: SPACE AND SIZE REQUIREMENTS:
Each trailer coach space must be not less than two thousand (2,000) square feet in area and should be at least twenty five feet (25') wide. (Prior code
§ 5-3-4(A))
8.16.100: SPACING REQUIRED:
A. The minimum spacing between trailer coaches and between trailer coaches and buildings must be:
1. Side to side spacing: Fifteen feet (15');
2. End to end spacing: Ten feet (10'). (Space between ends of trailer bodies, not chassis.)
B. No trailer should be located closer than twenty five feet (25') from the right of way line of a main highway or ten feet (10') from the trailer court
property line. (Prior code § 5-3-4(B))
8.16.110: ROADS AND WALKWAYS:
A. General Circulation: Safety and convenience must be a major consideration in the layout of roads, walks and parking areas within the trailer court. All
roads must be continuous.
B. Servicing: Suitable vehicular access for firefighting equipment, delivery of fuel, removal of garbage and refuse and for other necessary services must
be provided. Minimum service distances as required by local regulations or accepted practice must control.
C. Width Of Roads And Parking Areas: Main access roads, excluding parking: Two lane - twenty feet (20').
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 65/268
D. Parking Area: The same number of motor vehicle parking spaces must be provided as the number of trailer coach spaces. These must be provided in
special parking areas.
E. Walks:
1. Location: The trailer park walk system must include a walk from the entrance of each trailer to service facilities.
2. Width Of Walks:
a. Public walks, minimum: Four feet (4');
b. Entrance walks (from public walk to trailer door): Two feet (2'). (Prior code § 5-3-4(C))
8.16.120: SERVICE BUILDINGS:
Each trailer court must be provided with one or more service buildings containing the requisite number of plumbing fixtures and other service equipment.
The service buildings must conform in general to the following requirements:
A. Location: Buildings should be located not more than two hundred feet (200') from any dependent trailer coach spaces.
B. Construction: The materials and methods used in the construction of service buildings must conform to local building codes for buildings of this
nature. They must have an interior finish which is moisture resistant and can be easily cleaned. All rooms of service buildings must be ventilated and
all exterior openings provided with screens.
C. Facilities: Separate men's and women's toilet rooms must be provided and distinctly marked. These rooms must be separated by a sound resistant
wall. A vestibule or screen wall must be provided to prevent direct view into the toilet rooms when exterior doors are open.
1. Plumbing Fixtures:
a. Every trailer court must provide adequate toilet and laundry facilities. In no instance should there be less than one laundry unit (laundry tray or
washing machine); one water closet, one lavatory and one shower for women; and one water closet, one lavatory and one shower for men. A
slop water closet (water closet with seat removed) must be provided in each service building. The slop water closet should be in a separate
room of the service building with a single direct opening to the outside.
b. The facilities listed above will accommodate any number of independent trailer coaches, and up to ten (10) dependent trailer coaches. One
water closet must be provided for each sex for every ten (10) additional dependent trailer coaches. (Urinals for men may be substituted for onethird
(1/3) of these water closets.)
c. One lavatory must be provided for each sex for every ten (10) additional dependent coaches; and one shower or bathtub for each sex for every
twenty (20) additional dependent coaches. A laundry unit must be provided for every twenty (20) additional trailer coach spaces.
d. All water closets and bathtubs or showers for women, and all water closets and bathtubs for men must be located in separate compartments,
with self-closing doors. Gang type shower compartments may be used for men. Individual shower stalls must be approximately three feet by
three feet (3' x 3'). Showers for women must have a dressing compartment with stool or bench. The room containing the laundry units must be
separated from the toilet rooms, and have an exterior entrance only.
e. All plumbing installations shall conform to the local plumbing code.
2. Electrical: All electrical installations shall conform to the local electrical code.
3. Heating: Heating facilities capable of maintaining a temperature of seventy degrees (70°) in cold weather should be provided.
4. Hot Water:
a. Facilities should provide for the continuous supply of three (3) to five (5) gallons of hot water per trailer coach space.
b. Hot water at a temperature of about one hundred eighty degrees (180°) should be provided for clothes washing equipment. (Prior code § 5-3-
4(D))
8.16.130: LAUNDRY FACILITIES:
Mechanical laundry drying equipment or laundry drying yards must be provided. Laundry drying machines must be located in service buildings. Where
laundry drying yards are used, they must be conveniently located to service buildings and have an area of approximately five (5) square feet per trailer
coach space. (Prior code § 5-3-4(E))
8.16.140: REFUSE COLLECTION:
Refuse must be stored in flytight and rodentproof containers. Each coach space will require from four (4) to six (6) gallons of refuse storage capacity per
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 66/268
day. Refuse container stations, where used, should be located at a maximum of two hundred feet (200') from any trailer coach space and preferably not
more than one hundred fifty feet (150'). (Prior code § 5-3-4(F))
8.16.150: RECREATION AREA:
At least one hundred (100) square feet per trailer coach space must be made available in one or more areas for recreational uses. These areas should
be located so as to be free from traffic hazards. (Prior code § 5-3-4(G))
8.16.160: GRADING AND DRAINAGE REQUIREMENTS:
Grading and drainage must be performed so that water will drain away from trailer coach spaces, buildings, service and recreational areas, and off the
site in a manner which will provide reasonable freedom from erosion. Walks, driveways and retaining walls must be so constructed as not to interfere
with drainage. (Prior code § 5-3-5)
8.16.170: SLOPE REQUIREMENTS:
A. Trailer coach spaces must be graded toward abutting roadway to prevent surface water draining across adjacent coach spaces. Grading under
trailers must be provided to prevent puddling of water.
B. Where swales for the carriage of stormwater are needed between the trailer coach space and the roadway, they must be of a shallow type, generally
not to exceed eight inches (8") in depth, to permit the parking of the trailer without damage to the undercarriage.
C. The following minimum and maximum slope values will usually give satisfactory results:
Minimum
Percent
Maximum
Percent
Roads 0.50 0.8
Walks 0.50 10
Recreation area and laundry drying yards 0.50 4
Sodded and planted areas 1.00 10
Grade of coach space 0.50 5
(Prior code § 5-3-5(A))
8.16.180: CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
A. Roads And Parking Areas: Roads must be constructed of concrete or macadam, or of gravel, crushed stone, sand-clay, slag or other locally available
suitable materials, with a light bituminous surface treatment, oil coating or other dust preventive material. Roads must be crowned at center to shed
water to drainage facilities.
B. Walks: Walks must be constructed of concrete, macadam, gravel, fine stone, cinders or other materials providing a stable footing. Stepping stones
may be used from main walks to trailers.
C. Recreation Areas And Laundry Drying Yards: Surfacing may be natural ground cover, sand-clay or other suitable local materials. (Prior code § 5-3-
5(B))
8.16.190: WATER; REQUIREMENTS:
A safe and adequate supply of potable water must be provided in each trailer court.
A. Source Of Supply: Connection must be made to a public water supply.
B. Quantity: The minimum quantity of water to be provided must be one hundred twenty five (125) gallons per day per trailer coach space. Additional
quantities may be needed where lawn watering, car washing, are to be provided. Provision should generally be made for peak one hour domestic
requirements two and one-half (21/2) to three (3) times the average requirements. (Prior code § 5-3-6(A))
8.16.200: WATER; DISTRIBUTION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 67/268
A. The piping material and method of installation used for water distribution must conform to code requirements of the city plumbing code.
B. In general such systems must:
1. Be piped to all buildings containing plumbing fixtures, and to trailer coach spaces intended for use by coaches with plumbing fixtures;
2. Not be interconnected or cross connected with any other system of piping, or otherwise to be subject to hazards of backflow or back siphonage;
3. Be sized to provide water in sufficient volume and at adequate pressure for the sanitary operation of all plumbing fixtures during periods of
maximum demand. (Prior code § 5-3-6(B))
8.16.210: FIRE PROTECTION:
A. Where public water system is available to the trailer court, the recommendations of the local fire protection authorities should be obtained relative to
the installation of fire hydrants and other protective devices.
B. Where the trailer court water supply and distribution system is not intended to provide fire hose outlets, approved type portable fire extinguishers
should be provided in service buildings and at other suitable locations. (Prior code § 5-3-6(D))
8.16.220: DRINKING FOUNTAINS:
A. At least one drinking fountain must be provided in all trailer courts.
B. Drinking fountains, where installed, should be constructed of impervious material and should have an angle jet with the nozzle above the overflow rim
of the bowl. The nozzle should be protected by a nonoxidizing guard, and the bowl should be of easily cleanable design, without corners. The bowl
opening should have a strainer. The drain from the fountain should have a strainer. The drain from the fountain should have no direct, physical
connection with a waste pipe, unless the drain is trapped. (Prior code § 5-3-6(E))
8.16.230: PLUMBING CODE CONFORMANCE:
The plumbing installed in all trailer courts must conform to the city plumbing code. (Prior code § 5-3-6(F))
8.16.240: SEWER REQUIREMENTS:
A system of septic tanks shall be provided in all trailer courts and all waste and soil lines discharging from buildings and trailer coaches should be
connected thereto. All septic tanks and connections must be in accord with local practices and be approved by local administrative authorities having
jurisdiction. (Prior code § 5-3-6(G))
8.16.250: ELECTRICAL REQUIREMENTS:
A. Every trailer court must be provided with electric power. An electric outlet supplying one hundred ten (110) to one hundred fifteen (115) volts should
be provided for each coach space. The outlets should be weatherproof, and in easy reach of the parked trailer. In no instance should any power line
across the trailer court area be less than eighteen feet (18') above the ground. All electric wiring in the court must be in compliance with the village
electrical code.
B. Adequate over current protection must be provided on all circuits. Service drops to each coach space should be weatherproof, insulated, and not
smaller than two (2) no. 8 wires.
C. Street and yard lights, sufficient in number and intensity to permit the safe movement of vehicles and pedestrians at night must be provided. Outdoor
lighting must be effectively related to buildings, trees, walks, steps and ramps. (Prior code § 5-3-6(H))
8.16.260: FUEL RESTRICTIONS:
Cylinders, containing liquefied petroleum gas or oil to be used as fuel by trailer occupants, must be connected to the stoves or heaters of the trailer by
copper or other metallic tubing, to provide leakproof connections. The cylinders should be securely fastened in place, not less than five feet (5') from any
coach exit. State and local regulations applicable to the handling of bottled gas and fuel oil must be followed. All installations must conform to the city fire
preventive ordinance. (Prior code § 5-3-6(I))
8.16.270: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED GENERALLY:
A. Where restaurants, filling stations, fuel depots, stores, are provided as an added convenience to the tenants, such buildings and facilities must be
constructed and maintained in compliance with applicable local codes and health regulations.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 68/268
B. All ordinances, or parts of ordinances in conflict with the ordinance codified in this chapter, insofar as the ordinances in any way conflict with the
ordinance codified in this chapter, are repealed.
C. If any section, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter is for any reason held to be unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect the validity of the
remaining sections, sentences, clauses or phrases of this chapter, or the chapter as an entirety, it being the legislative intent that this chapter shall
stand notwithstanding the invalidity of such sections, sentence, clause or phrase.
D. Any violation of the provisions of this chapter, or any amendments thereto, is made a misdemeanor punishable as provided in title 1, chapter 1.24 of
this code, providing that each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 1152 § 7, 2008)

REFUSE AND STAGNANT WATER
8.24.010: PROHIBITION:

to or abutting upon any lot, block, place or premises or in any building or any shed owned or occupied by him or for which he may be agent within the
limits of the municipality, any stagnant water or impure water, refuse, vegetable decay or decaying substance, garbage or filth of any kind, nor suffer
such yard, lot, place, building or premises to be or to remain in such condition as to cause or create a nuisance or offensive smell or to pollute or render
unhealthful the atmosphere or the premises or create a rodent harborage, or thereby to be, become, cause or create a public nuisance. (Ord. 513 § 1,

Chapter 8.32
ABANDONED ICEBOXES, REFRIGERATORS AND CONTAINERS
8.32.010: RESTRICTIONS:
It is unlawful for any person to leave or permit to remain outside of any dwelling, building or other structure, or within any unoccupied or abandoned
building, structure or dwelling under his control, in a place accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or other
container which has a door or lid, snap lock or other locking device which may not be released from the inside, without first removing the door or lid,
snap lock or other locking device. (Prior code § 6-4-1)
Chapter 8.36
ABANDONED VEHICLES
8.36.010: DEFINITIONS:
ABANDONED: To leave a motor vehicle on private property without the permission of the person having rights to the possession of the property, or on a
public street or other property open to the public for the purposes of vehicular traffic or parking, or upon or within the right of way of any road or highway,
for twenty four (24) hours or longer.
FRONT YARD: A yard extending between side lot lines across the frontage of a lot adjoining a public street and from the front line to the front of the
principal building.
HIGHWAY: A way or place of whatever nature, publicly maintained and open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. Highway includes
street or alley.
PUBLIC PROPERTY: Does not include highway.
REAR YARD: A yard extending between side lot lines across the rear of a lot opposite the side(s) of a building which fronts upon a public street and
from the rear lot line to the rear of the principal building.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 69/268
VEHICLE: A device by which any person or property may be propelled, moved, or drawn upon a highway, except a device moved by human power or
used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks, including snowmobiles and all-terrain vehicles.
WRECKED, DISMANTLED OR INOPERATIVE VEHICLE: (The term inoperative vehicle when used alone shall include wrecked or dismantled vehicles.)
A vehicle which:
A. Does not carry a current valid state registration and license plates, or
B. Cannot be safely operated under its own power, or
C. Is visibly missing any part essential for movement, or on which such essential parts are broken or defective, including, but not limited to, missing
or flat tires, defective foot brakes, hand brakes, headlights, taillights, horn, muffler, rearview mirrors, windshield wipers or adequate fenders. (Ord.
1201, 2010)
8.36.020: NUISANCE DECLARED:
Pursuant to the authority granted by Idaho Code section 50-334 and correlated other provisions, the city council makes the following findings and
declarations:
The accumulation and storage of wrecked, dismantled or inoperative vehicles or parts thereof on private or public property is found to create a condition
tending to reduce the value of surrounding private property, to promote blight and deterioration, to invite plundering, to create fire hazards, to constitute
an attractive nuisance creating a hazard to the health and safety of minors, injurious to the health, safety and general welfare due to broken glass,
standing water, accumulation of rusted parts and potential for breeding of vermin.
Therefore, the presence of a wrecked, dismantled or inoperative vehicle, or part thereof, on private or public property except as expressly hereinafter
permitted is declared to constitute a public nuisance which may be abated as such in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 1201, 2010)
8.36.030: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
This chapter shall not apply to:
A. A vehicle or part thereof which is completely enclosed within a building in a lawful manner where it is not visible from the street or other public or
private property; or
B. A vehicle or part thereof which is stored or parked in a lawful manner on private property in connection with the business of a licensed vehicle dealer,
a licensed junk dealer, or when such storage or parking is necessary to the operation of a lawfully conducted business or commercial enterprise; or
to a vehicle under salvage permit as provided in section 8.36.060 of this chapter.
Nothing in this section shall authorize the maintenance of a public or private nuisance. (Ord. 1201, 2010)
8.36.040: UNLAWFUL TO LEAVE INOPERATIVE VEHICLES ON PUBLIC RIGHT OF WAY:
It is unlawful to leave inoperative vehicles on public right of way for a period longer than twenty four (24) hours. Removal of any inoperative vehicle from
public right of way may be removed in accordance with the procedures set forth in chapter 18, title 49, Idaho Code. (Ord. 1201, 2010)
8.36.050: UNLAWFUL TO LEAVE INOPERATIVE VEHICLES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
No person in charge or control of any property within the city, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee or otherwise, shall allow any inoperative or
unlicensed vehicle to remain on such property longer than forty eight (48) hours, and no vehicle shall at any time be in a state of major disassembly,
disrepair, or in the process of being stripped or dismantled unless pursuant to a salvage permit.
Except, one boat and/or one recreational vehicle without licenses may be stored in the side or rear yard, but not in any front yard. (Ord. 1201, 2010)
8.36.060: SALVAGE PERMIT:
Upon application of any person for a special permit and the payment of a nonrefundable fee in an amount set by resolution of the city council, the city
may cause a permit to be issued to such applicant for salvage of parts from one vehicle for necessary repairs of an existing vehicle registered to that
person. The permit will allow the presence of two (2) inoperative vehicles on the property: one vehicle being used as salvage and one vehicle being
repaired.
The length of time the permit can be issued will be determined by the following:
A. Salvage Permit For Thirty Days: If the conditions in subsection B of this section cannot be met, a thirty (30) day permit may be issued. At the end of
the thirty (30) day period, a city official may inspect the property and determine if the conditions for a six (6) month permit have been met. If those
conditions have not been met, a forty eight (48) hour notice will be given to have the vehicles and property in compliance or removed from the
premises. If the inoperative vehicle or any parts remain on the premises after the forty eight (48) hour notice, the same shall be removed and the cost
thereof charged to the permittee. A city official may also deny a permit for a good cause, including, but not limited to, the applicant's failure to comply
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 70/268
with the requirements of this chapter. In no case will a permit be issued if it appears that the applicant is or may be maintaining a business on the
property, no more than one permit may be issued to any property address.
B. Salvage Permit For Six Months: Vehicles and the property on which they reside must meet the following conditions before the salvage permit for six
(6) months can be issued:
1. Vehicles under salvage permit must be parked in compliance with general provisions and exceptions set forth in title 10, chapter 10.20 of this
code, and the appropriate zoning district parking requirements.
2. Vehicles under salvage permit are declared to require obstruction from public view and from adjoining properties by a solid opaque fence at least
six feet (6') in height.
3. Vehicles and the respective property on which they are located, that are maintained in a manner deemed to be detrimental to public health, safety,
or welfare due to broken glass, standing water, accumulation of rusted parts or potential for breeding of vermin, will have their salvage permits
revoked.
4. The above conditions must be maintained at all times or the permit will be revoked, and forty eight (48) hour notice given to have the vehicles and
property in compliance.
C. Further Action Upon Inspection: At the end of the six (6) month period, a city official may inspect the property. Upon demonstrating that significant
progress has been made on the repair or restoration of the vehicles under permit, up to three (3) further six (6) month renewals may be granted. At
the end of a renewal period(s), one or both vehicles must be in operating condition or removed, and all parts and waste removed from the property.
Failure to demonstrate significant progress will result in the permit being revoked and forty eight (48) hour notice is given to have the vehicles and
property in compliance or removed from the premises. If the inoperative vehicle or any parts remain on the premises after the forty eight (48) hour
notice, the same shall be removed and the cost thereof charged to the permittee.
D. Denial Of Permit: A city official may also deny a permit for a good cause, including, but not limited to, the applicant's failure to comply with the
requirements of this chapter. In no case will a permit be issued if it appears that the applicant is or may be maintaining a business on the property,
nor more than one permit may be in force or issued to any property address in any twelve (12) month period.
E. Painting Of Vehicles: Painting of vehicles is prohibited unless it is being done within an enclosed structure. (Ord. 1201, 2010)
8.36.070: ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER:
(Rep. by Ord. 1201, 2010)
8.36.080: APPEAL:
A. Any interested party may appeal the issuance, denial or revocation of a salvage permit or a notice to remove a vehicle by filing a written notice of
appeal with the city administrator within five (5) business days after the issuance of the notice to remove or the decision to issue, revoke or deny a
salvage permit.
B. Such appeal shall be heard by the city administrator which may affirm, amend or reverse the order or take other action deemed appropriate.
C. The clerk shall give written notice of the time and place of hearing to the appellant.
D. In conducting the hearing, the city administrator shall not be limited by the technical rules of evidence. (Ord. 1201, 2010)
8.36.090: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY:
A. Failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall constitute a misdemeanor. Nothing in this chapter shall limit the city's authority to also
pursue enforcement through whatever civil means are also available. The person violating this chapter shall be responsible for the city's costs
associated with civil enforcement action.
B. Prior to initiating prosecution for violation of this chapter, city staff shall attempt to provide notice to the person in charge or control of the real property
on which the violation has occurred. Such notice shall specify the nature of the violation and the time by which the violation must be abated. Said
notice shall be mailed to the person in charge or control of the property or delivered in person. If the person in charge or control cannot be found,
then notice shall be provided by posting a notice upon a conspicuous place on the premises and mailing a copy of said notice by certified mail to the
record owner reflected in the property tax records of the Kootenai County assessor of the same at such owner's address shown on those records.
(Ord. 1201, 2010)
8.36.100: REMOVAL COST, ASSESSMENT:
(Rep. by Ord. 1201, 2010)

8.36.110: ALTERNATIVE PROVISIONS:
This chapter is not the exclusive regulation of abandoned, wrecked, dismantled or inoperative vehicles within the city. It shall supplement and be in

Chapter 8.40
SALE OF PRODUCTS CONTAINING PHOSPHORUS
8.40.010: PURPOSE:
It is determined and declared to be necessary and conducive to and for the protection of the health, safety and welfare of the public inhabitants of the
city of Post Falls to prohibit, within the city limits, the sale or distribution of laundry cleaning products containing more than a trace amount of
phosphorus. (Ord. 589 § 1, 1990)
8.40.020: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following mean:
CITY: The city of Post Falls, Kootenai County, Idaho, or its authorized or designated agent, representative or deputy.
LAUNDRY CLEANING PRODUCT: Any product including, but not limited to, soaps, detergents, laundry bleaches and laundry additives used for the
purpose of cleaning laundry.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, corporation, unincorporated association, governmental entity or any other legal entity.
PHOSPHORUS: Elemental phosphorus.
TRACE QUANTITY: Any incidental amount of phosphorus which is not part of the laundry cleaning product formulation, and is present only as a
consequence of manufacturing, and does not exceed 0.5 percent of the content of the product by weight expressed as elemental phosphorus. (Ord. 589
§ 2, 1990)
8.40.030: SALE OF PHOSPHORUS PRODUCTS PROHIBITED:
No person may sell, distribute, offer or expose for sale, whether for domestic or commercial use, and whether at wholesale or retail within the city limits
any laundry cleaning product which contains phosphorus in excess of a trace quantity. (Ord. 589 § 3, 1990)
8.40.040: LABELING REQUIRED:
All laundry cleaning products sold within the city limits shall have affixed thereto labeling which clearly indicates the percent of phosphorus contained in
the product to the nearest one-tenth (1/10) of one percent (1%) accuracy. Laundry cleaning products which contain only a trace quantity of phosphorus
may be labeled "Contains no phosphorus", "Contains no phosphates", or similar labeling which makes a clear statement that no prohibited quantity of
phosphorus is present in the product. (Ord. 589 § 4, 1990)
8.40.050: TIME FOR COMPLIANCE:
To allow depletion of existing stock and for the convenience of sellers, the prohibition of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall not become effective
for ninety (90) days from the date of passage. (Ord. 589 § 5, 1990)
8.40.060: CUSTOMER NOTIFICATION:
Within ninety (90) days of passage of the ordinance codified in this chapter, all customers and residents of the city of Post Falls shall, by means selected
by the city, be notified of the initiation of the phosphate detergent ban program established by this chapter. (Ord. 589 § 6, 1990)
8.40.070: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY:
The provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by the city's police department. Any person involved in the sale or distribution of any laundry cleaning
compound prohibited by this chapter shall, for a first offense of this section, be notified of such noncompliance by the city and shall be given ten (10)
days from receipt of such notice to comply with the provisions of this chapter. Failure to comply with this section following this ten (10) day period, or
subsequent violations of any of the provisions of this section shall be a general misdemeanor and shall subject the person to the general penalty of title
1, chapter 1.24 of this code. (Ord. 1251, 2013: Ord. 589 § 8, 1990)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 72/268
Chapter 8.44
SPOKANE RIVER USE RESTRICTIONS
8.44.010: RESTRICTIONS ON USE OF SPOKANE RIVER AND ACCESS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to enter the waters of the Spokane River located within the boundaries of the city, or to enter the Spokane River from
any lands located within the city which are west of the Spokane Street Bridge across the Spokane River at any time a sign or message is posted on
either side of the Spokane Street Bridge across the Spokane River or on public park and boat launch property indicating that entry to, or use of, the
Spokane River is then prohibited. For purposes of this chapter, the term "entry" shall include launching a boat or other flotation device; piloting, floating
on or riding in a boat or on a flotation device; or swimming, wading, diving or otherwise subjecting oneself or others to the hazards of the Spokane River
as a result of conduct occurring within the city when prohibitory signs are posted. These limitations shall not apply to public safety or law enforcement
personnel or authorized personnel or contractors of the owner or operator of the Post Falls Dam in the course of performance of their assigned or
necessary duties. It shall constitute a violation of this code to engage in the proscribed conduct or to disregard any sign posted pursuant to the
restrictions established hereby. The penalty for any such violation shall be as provided in title 1, chapter 1.24 of this code. (Ord. 1236, 2012)
Chapter 8.48
BURIAL RESTRICTIONS
8.48.010: REQUIREMENTS FOR HUMAN BURIAL:
Notwithstanding any provision of law to the contrary, it shall be unlawful to bury or store the remains of any human body within the city except within a
cemetery owned or operated by political subdivision of the state or within a cemetery which complies with the endowment care cemetery act of the state,
or except where the remains are in the temporary care and custody of a public agency or public official, a state licensed funeral establishment or an
educational institution accredited or funded by the state. (Ord. 929 § 2, 1999)
Chapter 8.52
WEEDS, BUSHES, TREES AND OVERGROWN CONDITIONS; PROHIBITIONS
8.52.010: TERMS DEFINED:
The following terms shall have the following meanings when used in this chapter, unless the context of their use indicates otherwise:
BRUSH PILE: An accumulation of cuttings or dead portions of trees, brush or shrubs placed in a pile or allowed to lay randomly on the ground.
NUISANCE TREE OR SHRUB: Any large, woody perennial plant which is allowed to grow in such a manner as to obscure any traffic visibility triangle,
any traffic sign or encroach into a municipal public right of way in such a manner as to create a hazard to those using the right of way, or the existence of
any dead or dying tree or shrub which creates a hazard to public safety or public property.
VEGETATIVE LITTER: Scattered accumulation of dead portions of plant materials.
WEED: All uncultivated, unmowed grasses, annual plants, perennial plants, noxious weeds and all other rank uncultivated vegetation over eight inches
(8") tall, other than trees, shrubs, and cultivated plants, flowers and agricultural products. (Ord. 1024 § 2, 2003)
8.52.020: WEEDS, BUSHES, TREES AND OVERGROWN CONDITIONS UNLAWFUL:
A. It is unlawful for any owner, lessee, occupant, or any agent or representative of any such owner, lessee or occupant having control of any occupied or
unoccupied lot or parcel of land, or any part thereof in the city, to allow, permit or maintain on any such lot or land or any adjacent municipal public
right of way the growth of weeds, or unmowed grass or the accumulation of overgrown weeds, grass, brush, nuisance trees or shrubs, whether dead
or living. Allowing the unmanaged growth or accumulation of weeds (noxious or otherwise) or grass over eight inches (8") in height or the
accumulation or overgrowth of weeds, grass, brush or trees is declared to be a violation of this chapter. The owner of real property is ultimately
responsible for compliance with the requirements of this chapter.
B. All weeds, unmowed grasses, brush piles, and vegetative litter, with the exception of an actively operated compost pile not generating nuisance
odors, on any private property within the city are hereby declared to be a violation of this chapter.
C. Any tree, shrub or other plant material or any dead or dying tree or shrub located on private property in the city, which overhangs or intrudes over or
upon any public street, alley, avenue, roadway, sidewalk, traffic intersection visibility triangle or traffic sign to such an extent that it interferes with the
safety of the traveling public or is a hazard or hindrance to public safety or use of public property, is declared to be a violation of this chapter.
D. Pursuant to authority vested by Idaho Code section 50-317 or its successor and article XII, section 2 of the Idaho constitution, any owner, lessee,
occupant, or any agent or representative of any such owner, lessee or occupant having control of any occupied or unoccupied lot or parcel of land
shall be responsible for immediately remedying any conditions that violate the requirements of this chapter. Upon notice to the owner, the city is
empowered to abate such violation by causing the cutting and removal of trees, weeds, and grass, and the removal of rubbish upon and from private
property within the city and the parking within the curbing abutting same, and to assess the cost thereof against the private property so cleared, and
that which is adjacent to the parking/landscape strip between the sidewalks and curb and any alley so cleaned pursuant to Idaho Code section 50-
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 73/268
317 or its successor. Notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter, nothing addressed hereby shall preclude the city from acting upon conditions
that constitute a nuisance pursuant to provisions of Idaho Code and pursuing abatement as provided thereby. (Ord. 1024 § 2, 2003)
8.52.030: INITIATION OF COMPLAINTS:
Any person may file a weed, brush pile, vegetative litter or nuisance tree or shrub complaint by filing a written complaint with the city clerk or by reporting
such matters to the Post Falls police department. The city clerk shall forward all such complaints to the staff members assigned responsibility for
enforcement of this chapter by the city administrator. (Ord. 1024 § 2, 2003)
8.52.040: INSPECTION OF PREMISES AUTHORIZED:
City staff may determine by inspection whether such accumulation or growth or pile of weeds, brush or growth constitutes a violation of this chapter. It
shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with any authorized staff member or agent making an inspection permitted under this section. (Ord. 1024
§ 2, 2003)
8.52.050: NOTICE TO ABATE WEEDS, BUSHES, TREES AND OVERGROWN CONDITIONS:
Whenever a city staff member or authorized agent finds that a violation does exist pursuant to any provision of this chapter, he may initiate enforcement
by giving notice, by certified and first class mail addressed to the last known address of the owner of record or by personally serving the notice upon the
owner of record, and if there is more than one owner of record, by such mail or personal service to any one of such owners. In the event the owner of
the property is unknown, or his whereabouts are unknown, notice shall be given by a combination of first class mail and certified mail based upon the
records of the county assessor. Such notice shall specify the violations required to be abated and the manner and time limits by which the owner of the
property is required to achieve compliance. (Ord. 1024 § 2, 2003)
8.52.060: OWNER TO ABATE VIOLATION:
It shall be the duty of the owner of private property, whose use constitutes a violation of this chapter, to cut, trim or remove such accumulations or growth
immediately upon the receipt of notice from the city, in no case less than the time frame stated in the notice which shall provide at least five (5) days for
performance unless an emergency is found to exist. (Ord. 1024 § 2, 2003)
8.52.070: PENALTY FOR FAILURE TO ABATE VIOLATION:
Any owner or other person notified to cut, trim or remove weeds, brush pile, vegetative litter or nuisance tree or shrub growth from their property, and
who shall fail to do so and abate such violation within the time specified in the notice, shall be deemed guilty of an infraction, and upon conviction shall
be punished by fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00). If abatement is not accomplished within five (5) days after an infraction citation is issued the
violation may subsequently be charged as a misdemeanor punishable as provided in title 1, chapter 1.24 of this code. Every day such violation
continues after the date specified in the notice shall constitute a separate and distinct offense, punishable by a lawfully appropriate penalty. (Ord. 1152
§ 8, 2008)
8.52.080: APPEAL, TIME LIMITS FOR FILING AND DECISION:
If the property owner receiving notice to abate a violation of this chapter contests the determination, a written appeal of the notice may be filed with the
city clerk within no more than ten (10) days of transmittal of the notice to abate a violation. The city administrator shall hear the appeal as soon as
possible. A decision shall be rendered in writing by the city administrator as soon as practical. Any decision rendered by the city administrator shall be
final. (Ord. 1024 § 2, 2003)
8.52.090: ABATEMENT OF VIOLATIONS BY CITY AND COLLECTION OF COSTS:
In any case where a person required under this chapter does not abate the violation, the city, through its own personnel, contractor and/or agents, may
enter upon the premises to cut, trim or remove weeds, brush piles, vegetative litter or nuisance tree or shrub growth, and abate such violation. The total
cost of the abatement shall be billed to the owner of the property for payment. In the event payment is not made within sixty (60) days, or if the owner or
whereabouts of the owner are not known, the cost of abatement bill may be certified by the city clerk and forwarded to the county treasurer for inclusion
in the county property tax assessment pursuant to Idaho Code section 50-1008. Pursuit of abatement by the city shall not preclude prosecution of
violations of this chapter. (Ord. 1024 § 2, 2003)
Chapter 8.56
ELECTRONIC CIGARETTES
8.56.010: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
The purpose and intent of this chapter is to protect individuals under the age of eighteen (18) from the hazards of nicotine addiction and the dangers of
ingesting products with no regulatory oversight as to their purity, contents, and potential negative health impacts. (Ord. 1226, 2011)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 74/268
8.56.020: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter:
ELECTRONIC CIGARETTE OR E-CIGARETTE: An electronic device usually composed of a mouthpiece, a heating element or atomizer, a battery, and
electronic circuits that provides a gas derived from liquid nicotine and/or other substances which is inhaled by a user simulating smoking. The term
includes such devices, regardless of the details of the product appearance or marketed name, generally manufactured to resemble cigarettes, cigars,
pipes, or other smoking devices.
LIQUID NICOTINE: Any liquid product composed either in whole or part of nicotine, propylene glycol and/or other similar substances and manufactured
for use with an e-cigarette to be converted into a gas for inhaling.
PERSON: Any natural person, individual, corporation, limited liability company, unincorporated association, proprietorship, firm, partnership, joint
venture, joint stock association, or other entity or business of any kind.
PHOTOGRAPHIC IDENTIFICATION: State, district, territorial, possession, provincial, national or other equivalent government driver's license,
identification card or military card, in all cases bearing a photograph and a date of birth, or a valid passport. (Ord. 1226, 2011)
8.56.030: PROHIBITED ACTS:
A. No person may give, distribute, transfer, sell, market, or offer e-cigarettes, their components, or samples to persons under eighteen (18) years of age.
B. No person shall give or distribute e-cigarettes, or their components, to a person by a coupon if such coupon is redeemed in any manner that does not
require an in person transaction in a retail store to help prevent redemption of such merchandise by a person under eighteen (18) years of age.
C. No person under the age of eighteen (18) may purchase, attempt to purchase, possess, or obtain e-cigarettes or their components. This prohibition
does not apply to activities or enforcement actions under the control of a city, state, or federal law enforcement authority.
D. No person shall sell or permit to be sold e-cigarettes or their components through any device that mechanically dispenses such products unless the
device is located fully within premises from which persons under the age of eighteen (18) are prohibited, and not less than ten feet (10') from all
entrance or exit ways to and from each premises. (Ord. 1226, 2011)
8.56.040: REQUIRED SIGNAGE TO BE POSTED; IDENTIFICATION REQUIRED:
A. Any person selling, marketing, displaying, giving, or distributing e-cigarettes or their components shall display a printed sign, posted so that it is
clearly visible to anyone purchasing e-cigarettes or their components. The sign must be in contrasting colors and at least 20-point type and must
read substantially as follows:
IF YOU ARE UNDER 18, YOU COULD BE SUBJECT TO PENALTY FOR PURCHASING E-CIGARETTES OR RELATED DEVICES OR THEIR
COMPONENTS. THE SALE OF E-CIGARETTES OR RELATED DEVICES OR THEIR COMPONENTS TO PERSONS UNDER THE AGE OF 18 IS
STRICTLY PROHIBITED. PHOTO ID REQUIRED.
B. The failure of a person to request and examine photographic identification from a person under eighteen (18) years of age prior to the sale, gift or
distribution of e-cigarettes or related devices to such person shall be construed against the seller and form a conclusive basis for the seller's violation
of this chapter. (Ord. 1226, 2011)
8.56.050: PENALTIES, ENFORCEMENT AND DEFENSES:
A. Violation of any provision of this chapter shall be a misdemeanor. Each transaction is a new and separate violation.
B. It is a defense to a prosecution for violation of this chapter relating to age when the person making the gift, distribution, transfer, sale, marketing, or
offer as a gift, transfer, sale, marketing, or sample reasonably relied on an officially issued photographic identification showing the purchaser or
recipient was at least eighteen (18) years old.
C. It is a defense to subsection 8.56.030D of this chapter if the person demonstrates to the satisfaction of the building official that it is architecturally
impracticable for the device to be located not less than ten feet (10') from all entrance and exit ways. (Ord. 1226, 2011)
Title 9
PUBLIC PEACE, MORALS AND WELFARE
Chapter 9.04
INCHOATE OFFENSES
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 75/268
9.04.010: AIDING, ABETTING PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person, in any way or manner, to aid, abet, counsel, advise or encourage any other person in the commission of any of the acts
mentioned in chapters 9.08 through 9.24; 9.28, articles I and II; 9.32 and 9.40 of this title or in any manner encourage the commission of such offense
defined by chapters 9.08 through 9.24; 9.28, articles I and II; 9.32 and 9.40 of this title. (Prior code § 6-1-2)
Chapter 9.08
OFFENSES BY OR AGAINST PUBLIC OFFICERS AND GOVERNMENT
9.08.010: IMPERSONATING AN OFFICER PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to represent falsely himself to be an officer of the municipality or who shall attempt to impersonate any such officer or who
shall without authority perform any official act therein on behalf of an officer. (Prior code § 6-1-17)
9.08.020: RESISTING OR INTERFERING WITH OFFICER PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to interfere wilfully with, resist, delay, obstruct, molest or threaten to molest any officer of the municipality in the exercise of
his official duties. (Prior code § 6-1-38)
9.08.030: ASSISTANCE REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any citizen over the age of eighteen (18) years to refuse or neglect to render assistance to any police officer when called upon for such
assistance or aid in the suppression of riot or other unlawful assemblage or in the arrest of any person who has committed an offense. (Ord. 506 § 1,
1986: prior code § 6-1-22)
9.08.040: ESCAPE FROM PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person convicted of any offense or in lawful custody to escape or attempt to escape from custody. (Prior code § 6-1-14)
9.08.050: AIDING ESCAPE FROM PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to aid or assist any person to escape from lawful confinement or to assist any person to escape from the custody of any
peace officer. (Prior code § 6-1-1)
9.08.060: FURNISHING PRISONERS WITH WEAPONS OR DRUGS PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to furnish or attempt to furnish or take into jail or to deliver or attempt to deliver to any prisoner therein confined, or in the
custody of any officer, any weapon, tool, intoxicating liquors, drug or other article without the consent of the officer in charge. (Prior code § 6-1-19)
Chapter 9.12
OFFENSES AGAINST THE PERSON
9.12.010: ASSAULT OR BATTERY:
It is unlawful for any person to commit assault or battery. (Prior code § 6-1-3)
9.12.020: FRAUD; TO OBTAIN GOODS:
It is unlawful for any person to obtain any food, drink, goods, wares or merchandise under false pretenses, or to enter any public place and call for
refreshments or other articles and receive and refuse to pay for same, or depart without paying for or satisfying the person from whom he received the
food, goods, wares and merchandise. (Prior code § 6-1-16)
9.12.030: FRAUD; TO OBTAIN MONEY:
It is unlawful for any person, who by color, or aid of any trick or sleight of hand performance, or by fraud or by fraudulent scheme, cards, dice or device,
to win for himself or another any money or property or a representative of either. (Prior code § 6-1-41)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 76/268
Chapter 9.16
OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY
9.16.010: FRAUDULENT AVOIDANCE:
It is unlawful for any person fraudulently to enter, without payment of the proper admission fee, any theater, ballroom, lecture, concert or other place
where admission fees are charged; provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall be deemed to prohibit or restrict the free admission of police
officers engaged in the performance of police duties to any place of public entertainment or amusement. (Prior code § 6-1-18)
9.16.020: SHOPLIFTING:
Whoever, without authority, wilfully conceals the goods, wares or merchandise of any store or merchant while upon the premises of such store or
merchant shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in title 1, chapter 1.24 of this code. Goods, wares
or merchandise found concealed upon the person shall be prima facie evidence of a wilful concealment. (Ord. 1152 § 9, 2008)
9.16.030: TAKING DOWN FENCE OR OPENING GATE OF ANOTHER:
It is unlawful for any person to take down any fence or to let down any bars to open any gate in or on the property of another without the consent of the
owner, occupant or person in charge thereof. (Prior code § 6-1-42)
9.16.040: MALICIOUS MISCHIEF:
It is unlawful for any person wilfully and maliciously to injure, deface, mutilate, remove, pull down, break or in any manner interfere with or molest or
secrete or destroy any real or personal property belonging to or under the control of any person. (Prior code § 6-1-31)
9.16.050: TRESPASS:
Every person who wilfully commits trespass by either:
A. Every person, except under landlord-tenant relationship, who, being first notified in writing, or verbally by the owner or authorized agent of the owner
of real property or a police officer, to immediately depart from the same and who refuses to so depart after being so notified; or
B. Every person, except under landlord-tenant relationship, who, being first notified in writing, or verbally by the owner or authorized agent of the owner
of real property or a police officer, to depart and not return to the same and who does return after being so notified, is guilty of a misdemeanor.
The foregoing provision shall not apply to any law enforcement, emergency medical or public safety officer or other person lawfully entering property
pursuant to his or her official duties or an emergency situation. (Ord. 794 § 1, 1995)
9.16.060: THEFT OF RENTAL PROPERTY:
A. A person steals property and commits theft when, with intent to deprive another of property or to appropriate the same to himself or to a third person,
he wrongfully takes, obtains or withholds such property from an owner thereof.
B. It shall be prima facie evidence that a person knowingly obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner when a lessee of the
personal property of another, leased or rented by written instrument specifying the time and place the personal property is to be returned, fails to
return the personal property to the owner:
1. Within ninety (90) days; or
2. Within seventy two (72) hours after written demand for return thereof is personally served or given by registered mail to the last known address
provided in such lease or rental agreement.
C. Any person convicted of such theft shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in title 1, chapter 1.24 of this code. (Ord. 1152
§ 10, 2008)
Chapter 9.20
OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE
9.20.010: PROHIBITING AGGRESSIVE SOLICITATION PRACTICES AND SOLICITATION OF FUNDS FROM OCCUPANTS OF
MOTOR VEHICLES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 77/268
A. Solicitation Of Vehicle Occupants Prohibited In Public Highway Right Of Way Open To Vehicular Traffic: In order to prevent possible injury to
pedestrians or distraction of motorists leading to auto crashes, it shall be unlawful for any person to sit or stand on a highway, as defined in Idaho
Code 49-109(5) open to vehicular traffic to solicit business or contributions from the occupants of any vehicle.
B. Aggressive Soliciting Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in aggressive solicitation in any public place. For purposes of this
section "aggressive solicitation" is defined as:
1. Continuing to solicit from a person after the person has given a negative response to the soliciting;
2. Intentionally touching or causing physical contact with another person without that person's consent in the course of soliciting;
3. Blocking, obstructing or interfering with the free passage of a pedestrian or vehicle by any means, including unreasonably causing a pedestrian or
vehicle operator to take evasive action to avoid physical contact in the course of soliciting;
4. Exhibiting threatening conduct or manner toward a person solicited which would cause a reasonable person to be fearful for his or her safety
and/or the safety of his or her property;
5. Persisting in closely following or approaching the person being solicited and continuing to solicit after the person has informed the solicitor by
words or conduct that the person does not want to be solicited or does not want to give money or anything of value to the solicitor;
6. Using profane or abusive language in the course of solicitation that would be likely to provoke an immediate defensive reaction from the person
being solicited or would cause a reasonable person to be fearful for his or her safety or well being;
7. Soliciting money from anyone who is in a fixed location whether waiting in line for tickets, waiting to enter a building at a particular place or for
another purpose that limits the ability of a person solicited to move away from a solicitor.
C. Limiting Solicitation In Certain Circumstances: It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in solicitation in any place to which the public or a
substantial part of the public has access, including streets, highways, transportation facilities, schools, places of amusement, parks, playgrounds and
the common areas of public and private buildings and facilities, including parking lots or any other area intended for use by the public in any of the
following circumstances:
1. To solicit funds or business on any private or residential property after having been asked to leave, or to refrain from soliciting, by the owner or
other person lawfully in possession of the real property.
2. Without permission of the owner or other person lawfully in possession of the real property, to solicit within twenty feet (20') of any automated teller
machine. Provided, however, that when an automated teller machine is located within an enclosed automated teller machine facility, the distance
shall be measured from the entrance or exit of the facility.
3. To solicit for funds or business in or upon any public transportation vehicle or public transportation facility, at any bus stop or in any public parking
lot, structure or other parking facility operated by a public agency.
4. To solicit for funds or business activity within ten feet (10') of an entrance to a building fronting upon public property or a public highway as defined
by Idaho law, unless permission is expressly granted by the owner of the abutting business.
5. To solicit funds or business activity from any person entering or exiting a parked motor vehicle or in a motor vehicle stopped on a public street.
6. To solicit funds or business activity from any person located within the patio or sidewalk area of a retail business establishment that serves food
and/or drink.
7. To solicit funds or business activity from one-half (1/2) hour after sunset until one-half (1/2) hour before sunrise, except as may be otherwise
allowed at any time on private property by permission of the business and/or landowner. (Ord. 1247, 2013)
9.20.020: DISTURBING THE PEACE:
A. It is unlawful for any person, wilfully or maliciously, to disturb the peace and quiet of another or of any neighborhood or family or religious
congregation or other assembly by loud or unusual noises or indecent behavior or by offensive or unbecoming conduct or for any person to threaten,
quarrel, fight or provoke an assault or battery or utter any obscene or fighting words in the presence of another.
B. It is further unlawful for any person who owns, leases, or has custody and control of a motor vehicle equipped with an audible vehicle alarm to allow
said alarm to sound in excess of ten (10) minutes on any single occasion before said alarm automatically terminates or is manually terminated by the
responsible owner, lessee, or custodian; in excess of three (3) separate alarms, regardless of duration, in any consecutive seven (7) day period; or in
excess of five (5) separate alarms, regardless of duration, in any consecutive twenty eight (28) day period. Each alarm which exceeds the maximums
established hereby, either with respect to duration or frequency, shall constitute a separate offense, each of which shall be punishable as a
misdemeanor. It shall be a defense against a charge of violation of the ordinance provisions which prohibit repeated vehicle alarms to provide proof
that an actual attempt to break and enter the vehicle in question has occurred. Any circumstance where a responsible person provides preponderant
evidence that an actual break in attempt has occurred shall be disregarded in calculating the multiple alarms which constitute a violation of this
section. (Ord. 833 § 1, 1996: Ord. 524 § 2, 1986: prior code § 6-1-11)
9.20.030: UNLAWFUL ASSEMBLY:
It is unlawful for two (2) or more persons to assemble together for the purpose of disturbing the peace or for the purpose of committing an unlawful act
and not to disperse upon the command of an officer so to do. (Prior code § 6-1-43)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 78/268
9.20.040: RIOT:
It is unlawful for any person to fail or refuse immediately to disperse upon an order to do so by a police officer, when two (2) or more persons are
assembled for the purpose of disturbing the peace or for the purpose of committing any unlawful act. (Prior code § 6-1-39)
Chapter 9.24
OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC DECENCY
9.24.010: OBSCENE LITERATURE; DISTRIBUTION PROHIBITED:
A. It is unlawful for any person to exhibit, pass, give or deliver to another any obscene book, pamphlet, picture, card, print, paper, writing, mold, cast or
figure.
B. "Obscene" means that material which depicts sexual acts or conduct that taken as a whole appeals to prurient sexual interests and is without
redeeming social value, as judged by contemporary community standards. (Ord. 524 § 2, 1986: prior code § 6-1-10)
9.24.020: LEWD CONDUCT:
It is unlawful for any person to urinate or stool in any place open to the public view, or to be guilty of any lewd, lascivious or obscene conduct in any
public place. (Ord. 524 § 2, 1986: prior code § 6-1-34)
9.24.030: INDECENT EXPOSURE:
It is unlawful for any person to appear in a state of nudity in any public place or in any such place to make any intentional exposure of his or her person
or private parts thereof, or the private parts of another, or to wear clothing that fails to keep such private parts hidden from the view of others. (Ord. 524
§ 2, 1986: prior code § 6-1-25)
9.24.040: PROSTITUTION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to pursue or advertise in any manner her vocation as a prostitute or for any person to advertise the profession of a
prostitute or solicit for a prostitute. (Prior code § 6-1-37)
9.24.050: HOUSE OF PROSTITUTION:
It is unlawful for any person to keep or assist in the keeping of a house of ill fame or prostitution or knowingly to reside therein or knowingly to rent, lease
or permit any person to occupy any house or room owned, leased or controlled by him for this purpose. (Prior code § 6-1-23)
9.24.060: GAMBLING:
It is unlawful for any person to deal, play or conduct, either as owner, employee or lessee, whether or not for hire, any game played with cards, dice or
any other device for money, checks, credit or other representative of value. (Prior code § 6-1-20)
9.24.090: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS:
It is unlawful for any person to torture or beat cruelly, starve or otherwise ill treat any animal in his care or charge, whether belonging to himself or any
other person. (Prior code § 6-1-7)

OFFENSES BY OR AGAINST MINORS
Article I. Delinquency
9.28.010: ENCOURAGING PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person, by any act or neglect, to encourage, aid or cause a child to come within the purview of the juvenile authorities; and it shall
likewise be unlawful for any person, after notice that a driver's license of any child has been suspended or revoked, to permit such child to operate a
motor vehicle during the period that such driver's license is suspended. (Prior code § 6-1-13)
