Article II. Alcoholic Beverages
9.28.020: ALCOHOL; FURNISHING WITH AND PURCHASE BY PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to procure, sell or give away any beer, wine, liquor, or other alcoholic beverage to any person under the age proscribed by
Idaho Code section 23-949 or for any person under the age proscribed by said statute to purchase, attempt to purchase or otherwise procure, consume
or have in his possession any beer, wine, liquor, or other alcoholic beverage. (Ord. 571 § 1, 1989: Ord. 507 § 1, 1986: prior code § 6-1-6)
9.28.030: FURNISHING WITH TOBACCO PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to sell or give away, directly or indirectly, to any person under the age of eighteen (18) years any cigarettes, tobacco or any
compounds of tobacco used in filling up or making of a cigarette or to give or sell any cigarette papers to minors. Every minor person under the age of
eighteen (18) years who shall buy, accept or have in his possession any cigarette, cigar or tobacco in any form, or who shall buy, accept or have in his
possession any cigarette paper or other paper or wrapper intended for the wrapping of tobacco in the form of a cigarette, shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor. (Ord. 683 § 1, 1992: Ord. 507 § 1, 1986: prior code § 6-1-40)
Article III. Curfew
9.28.040: DEFINITIONS:
EMERGENCY: An unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss
of life. The term includes, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, automobile accident, or any other situation requiring immediate action to prevent
serious bodily injury or loss of life.
ESTABLISHMENT: Any place of business to which the public is invited, including, but not limited to, any place of amusement or entertainment.
GUARDIAN: A. A person, who, under court order, is the guardian of the person of a minor; or
B. A public or private agency with whom a minor has been placed by a court.
MINOR: Any person less than eighteen (18) years of age, except for persons emancipated by either marriage or by court order.
PARENT: A person who is:
A. A natural parent, stepparent or adoptive parent; or
B. A person at least eighteen (18) years of age and authorized by a parent or legal guardian to have the care and custody of the minor.
PRIVATE PROPERTY OPEN TO THE PUBLIC: Real property not owned by the federal government or the state of Idaho or any of its political
subdivisions, but is available for vehicular traffic or parking by the general public or customers of the business.
PUBLIC PLACE: Any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access and includes, but is not limited to, streets, highways, and
the common areas of schools, apartment houses, office buildings, retail stores/complexes, recreational facilities, and shops. (Ord. 1195 § 2, 2010)
9.28.050: CURFEW ESTABLISHED:
A. It is unlawful for any minor to be upon any public place or private property open to the public between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight and
five o'clock (5:00) A.M. unless the person is accompanied by a parent, legal guardian or any other adult person lawfully and properly accompanying
the minor person, or unless provided for herein.
B. It is unlawful for any parent or legal guardian to knowingly permit or allow the minor to be present, without a specific purpose and without a parent or
guardian, in any public place or private property open to the public within the city during curfew hours.
C. It is unlawful for an owner, operator, or any employee of an establishment to knowingly allow a minor, without permission of a parent or guardian, to
be present upon the premises of the establishment during curfew hours, unless the establishment is involved in rendering services for an emergency
or is a designated "safe place" and the minor is seeking emergency help, shelter, or care. It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the
owner, operator, or employee of an establishment asked the minor to leave the premises and promptly notified the law enforcement department for
the city that a minor is present on the premises of the establishment during curfew hours and refuses to leave. (Ord. 1195 § 2, 2010)
9.28.060: EXCEPTIONS:
The provisions of this article shall not apply in cases where the minor is:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 80/268
A. Accompanied by the minor's parent or guardian;
B. On an errand at the direction of the minor's parent or guardian, without any unauthorized detour, delay or stop;
C. In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel;
D. Engaged in an employment activity, or going to or returning home from an employment activity, without any unauthorized detour, delay or stop;
E. Involved in an emergency;
F. Attending an official school, religious, recreational, or other activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the city of Post Falls, a civic organization,
or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor, or going to or returning home from such activity, without any unauthorized detour,
delay or stop; or
G. Exercising first amendment rights protected by the United States constitution, such as the right of free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and
the right of assembly, or going to or returning from such activity, without any unauthorized detour, delay, or stop. (Ord. 1195 § 2, 2010)
9.28.070: FAILURE TO PICK UP MINOR:
It is unlawful and shall be considered a separate offense under this article for any parent, guardian or other adult person having the legal care and
custody of such minor, after being notified to do so by a law enforcement officer, to refuse to come immediately to any location designated by a law
enforcement officer where the child is ordered to remain for pick up and to refuse to take charge of such minor. (Ord. 1195 § 2, 2010)
9.28.080: JUVENILE RUNAWAYS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any minor to leave the city of Post Falls residence of a parent or legal guardian, without the permission of the parent or legal
guardian, with the intent of staying away from, or at a distance from, the residence. This section is not intended to apply to a minor leaving the residence
for a visit to a neighbor or friend that is less than twelve (12) hours and is not overnight, if the circumstances support that there was an intent at the time
the minor left the residence to return the same day.
A. The following are prima facie evidence of an intent to stay away, but are not intended to be the only evidence of intent to stay away:
1. Failure or refusal to return to the residence after a parent or legal guardian has requested the minor to return to the residence and the request has
been communicated to the minor either orally or in writing.
2. Failure or refusal to return to the residence after a law enforcement officer has advised the minor that the parent or legal guardian has requested
the minor to return to the residence.
3. Wilfully fleeing or attempting to elude a law enforcement officer after being lawfully ordered to stop.
4. Wilfully failing or refusing to answer a telephone, or respond to a text or e-mail message, from the parent or guardian, or from a law enforcement
officer.
5. Removal of the minor's clothing from the residence.
6. Oral or written statements of an intent or a threat to leave and not return. (Ord. 1232, 2012)
9.28.090: PENALTIES:
A person who violates a provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor. In the event that the person is a minor, a violation of this chapter may form
the basis for a petition for proceedings pursuant to the juvenile corrections act. (Ord. 1195 § 2, 2010)
Chapter 9.32
CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES
9.32.010: MARIJUANA PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to possess any part of the plant Cannabis sativa L. (marijuana) either growing or not, the seeds thereof, the resin extracted
from any pad of the plant, and every compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of the plant, its seed or resin. (Prior code § 6-1-47)
9.32.020: DRUG PARAPHERNALIA:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 81/268
It is unlawful for any person to use, or possess with intent to use, drug paraphernalia, as defined by state of Idaho statute 37-2701(n), to plant,
propagate, cultivate, grow, harvest, manufacture, compound, convert, produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store, contain, conceal,
inject, ingest, inhale, or otherwise introduce into the human body a controlled substance as defined by Idaho state statute 37-2701(e). (Ord. 575 § 1,
1989)
Chapter 9.36
WEAPONS
9.36.010: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms, whenever used in this chapter, have the following meanings:
FIREARMS: Any instrument used in the propulsion of shot, pellets, or bullets, or other harmful objects by the action of gunpowder exploded within it, or
by the action of compressed air within it, or by the power of springs, and including what are commonly known as air rifles and BB guns.
MANUALLY OPERATED THROWING DEVICE: Bow and arrows, slingshots, and any other instrument used to propel any object by mechanical or
manually operated means. (Ord. 730 § 1, 1993: prior code § 6-5-1)
9.36.020: CONCEALED PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to carry concealed upon his person any brass knuckles, revolver, pistol, dagger, stiletto or other deadly or dangerous
weapon unless the person has secured a concealed weapons permit from the sheriff of the county, or the jurisdiction in which they reside if they are not
a resident of the state of Idaho, or is otherwise authorized by the laws of the state of Idaho to carry a concealed weapon without a permit. (Ord. 1006
§ 1, 2002: Ord. 518 § 1, 1986: prior code § 6-5-2)
9.36.030: DISCHARGE PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to discharge firearms or manually operated throwing devices of any kind or description within the limits of the municipality;
provided, however, that this shall not apply to police officers in the discharge of their duties. Military honor guards performing at funerals or at public
events and performers in theatrical productions or firearms demonstrations may, with the permission of the chief of police or his designee, discharge
firearms using blanks.
A. Exceptions:
1. A person may discharge a firearm on properties that are zoned to allow agricultural use, if discharge of the firearm is for the purpose of
slaughtering animals raised on the property for the purpose of human consumption, or the property is zoned to allow the slaughter and packaging
of meat for human consumption, and the person discharging the firearm complies with the following conditions:
a. The discharge of the firearm is aimed away from persons, vehicles, roadways, buildings constructed for human occupancy, and other animals;
b. The slaughter of the animal is not visible from a public roadway; and
c. The person discharging the firearm provides prior notice to the law enforcement agency for the city.
2. A person discharging a firearm in the lawful defense of person or persons or property. (Ord. 1271, 2014)
9.36.040: EXCEPTION; PERMIT:
The governing body may at any time, upon receipt of proper application, grant permits to shooting galleries, gun clubs and others for shooting in fixed
localities and under specified rules. Such permits shall be in writing attested by the clerk conforming to such requirements as the governing body shall
demand, and the permit thus issued shall be subject to revocation at any time by action of the governing body. (Prior code § 6-5-4)
Chapter 9.40
MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES
9.40.010: BARBED WIRE OR ELECTRIC FENCES:
It is unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any electric fence or any fence constructed in whole or in part of barbed wire or to use barbed wire as a
guard to any parking lot or parcel of land, unless the person or entity seeking to erect the fence has made an application to the planning and zoning
commission and the commission has approved the application. The commission shall approve the application upon its determination that the following
conditions have been met:
A. The applicant has shown that he has good cause for the use of such a fence and that the fence will not be harmful to the general public;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 82/268
B. The fence is to be located: (Ord. 517 § 1, 1986: prior code § 6-1-5)
1. In an area zoned either heavy industrial, industrial unit development, planned unit development or educational district as defined and described in
the zoning ordinance, (Ord. 1241, 2012: Ord. 517 § 1, 1986: prior code § 6-1-5)
2. In an area not zoned as set out in subsection B1 of this section, but that contains a dangerous or sensitive public facility like an electric plant or a
water reservoir, or
3. In areas that are zoned for agricultural or livestock use and then only to keep livestock fenced in or out;
C. Except in areas zoned for agricultural or livestock use, the fence is to be constructed in the following manner:
1. Located at the top of nonbarbed fence and beginning at a height of not less than six feet (6') from the level of the ground, but not making the total
height of the fence above eight feet (8'),
2. The barbed wire portion of the fence must be included toward the area to be protected at an angle of not less than forty five degrees (45°),
3. The barbed wire portion of the fence shall not consist of more than three (3) strands;
D. In the case of the fence being used in an area zoned for agricultural or livestock use, the fence shall be constructed as follows:
1. The fence shall not exceed four and one-half feet (41/2') in height,
2. No more than four (4) strands of barbed wire shall be used,
3. The strands of barbed wire shall be at least eight inches (8") apart,
4. The fence is to be marked in such manner as to be clearly visible to the public. (Ord. 517 § 1, 1986: prior code § 6-1-5)
9.40.020: LITTERING; INJURIOUS MATERIAL:
A. It is unlawful for any person to deposit, place or allow to remain in or upon any public thoroughfare any material or substance injurious to person or
property.
B. It is unlawful for any person to scatter or throw upon the public thoroughfares any handbills, posters, advertisements or papers. Nothing herein shall
be construed to authorize any person to obstruct the public thoroughfares or create any nuisance therein.
C. No vehicle shall be driven or moved on any street or highway unless the vehicle is so constructed, covered, or loaded as to prevent any of its
contents or load from dropping, sifting, leaking, blowing, spilling or otherwise escaping therefrom. (Ord. 1055 § 2, 2004: prior code § 6-1-8)
9.40.030: SPITTING:
It is unlawful for any person to expectorate or spit upon any sidewalk or upon the floor of any public building or room used for public assemblies. (Prior
code § 6-1-15)
9.40.040: KEEPING OF JUNK RESTRICTED:
It is unlawful for any person to store or keep any old articles or materials which may be classified as junk, adjacent to or in close proximity to any
schoolhouse, church, public park, public grounds, business buildings or residences without first providing proper and tight buildings for the storage of the
same. "Junk" shall mean old iron, steel, brass, copper, tin, lead or other base metals; old cordate, ropes, rags, fibers or fabrics; old rubber; old bottles or
other glass; bones; wastepaper and other waste or discarded materials which might be prepared to be used again in some form; and any or all of the
foregoing. Junk shall not include materials or objects accumulated by a person as byproducts, waste, scraps from the operation of his own business or
materials or objects held and used by a manufacturer as an integral part of his own manufacturing processes. (Ord. 516 § 1, 1986: prior code § 6-1-26)
9.40.050: USE OF LOUDSPEAKER OR SOUND TRUCK:
A. It is unlawful to play, operate or use any device known as a sound truck, loudspeaker or sound amplifier, radio or phonograph, with loudspeakers or
sound amplifier or any instrument of any kind or character which emits loud noises and is attached to or upon any vehicle unless such person in
charge of such vehicle shall have first applied to and received a written permit from the chief of police to operate any such vehicle so equipped.
B. The permit is to be granted upon the party seeking the permit agreeing to obey the following rules and limitations:
1. The sound truck may only amplify music or human speech.
2. The hours of operation shall be limited to eleven thirty o'clock (11:30) A.M. to one thirty o'clock (1:30) P.M. and four thirty o'clock (4:30) P.M. to six
thirty o'clock (6:30) P.M. Monday through Saturday.
3. The sound truck shall travel at least ten (10) miles per hour unless held up by traffic; if the truck is held up more than one minute the equipment
shall be turned off for the duration of such stop.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 83/268
4. The truck shall not amplify profanity, lewd, indecent or slanderous remarks.
5. Sounds shall not be issued within one hundred (100) yards of hospitals, schools or churches.
6. The volume of sound shall not be audible for a distance in excess of one hundred feet (100') from the sound truck and shall not be unreasonably
loud, jarring, disturbing or a nuisance to persons within the area of audibility.
C. Violations of these rules may lead to a revocation of the permit to operate a sound truck. (Ord. 520 § 1, 1986: prior code § 6-1-29)
9.40.060: LUG WHEELS:
It is unlawful for tractors with wheels injurious to pavement to be permitted upon the public thoroughfares unless the operator of such vehicle shall first
plank such streets. (Prior code § 6-1-30)
9.40.070: WATER FLOWING ON STREETS:
It is unlawful for any person to allow any water to flow into or upon any public thoroughfare. (Prior code § 6-1-45)
9.40.080: ARTICLES ON WINDOWSILLS:
It is unlawful for any person to place or keep on any windowsill, porch or other projection above the first story of any building abutting on any sidewalk
any article which might do injury by falling upon any person on the sidewalk in front of such building, unless the article be securely fastened or protected
by screens. (Prior code § 6-1-46)
9.40.090: POINTING LASER POINTER AT PUBLIC OFFICER:
A. As referred to in this section the term "laser pointer" shall mean any device that emits light amplified or concentrated by the stimulated emission of
radiation that is visible to the human eye.
B. It shall be unlawful for any person to direct light from a laser pointer at a uniformed police officer, uniformed security guard, uniformed emergency
communications officer, uniformed fireman, uniformed emergency medical worker, or other uniformed city, state or federal peace officer, or at the
marked vehicle or into the public office of any such individual. (Ord. 933 § 1, 1999)
9.40.100: ATTACHMENTS TO UTILITY POLES:
It is unlawful for any person to post, paint, tack or otherwise attach any notices or advertising matter not regulated under title 18 of this code to any
public or private utility pole or to any fence, wall or building or other property until first obtaining the consent of the owner of the property. (Ord. 1055 § 3,
2004)
Chapter 9.44
EMERGENCY ALARM SYSTEMS
9.44.010: TERMS DEFINED:
In construing the provisions of this chapter, except where otherwise plainly declared or clearly apparent from the context, words shall be given their
common and ordinary meaning, and in addition, the following definitions shall apply:
ALARM SYSTEM: Any assembly of equipment, mechanical, electrical or electronic, designed to alert an alarm service company, law enforcement
agency, the public, or any person or any public emergency response entity, of the commission or attempted commission of a crime, or occurrence of
another emergency, at a particular location, excluding vehicle alarms.
FALSE ALARM: The activation of a burglary, robbery, or other emergency alarm for the purpose of summoning the police or other public emergency
responders, including fire or medical, when no burglary, robbery, or other emergency is being committed, attempted, or is occurring on the premises.
(Ord. 827 § 1, 1995)
9.44.020: ALARM SYSTEM PRACTICES AND CHARACTERISTICS PROHIBITED OR REQUIRED:
The following alarm system methods, practices, or characteristics are prohibited or required, as appropriate, within the corporate limits of the city:
A. Systems designed to alert any law enforcement agency of an emergency by providing unattended automatic dialing to any law enforcement agency
or any emergency response (9-1-1) system for the purpose of transmitting a preprogrammed signal, message, or code.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 84/268
B. Systems which lack a standby backup power source which will automatically assume the operation of the alarm system without activating the alarm.
C. Systems which do not automatically shut off their audible alarm within a maximum of twenty (20) minutes of its activation or which do not have an
automatic cutoff with a rearming phase which is able to distinguish between an open and closed circuit, preventing rearming if the circuit is open, to
prevent recurring false alarms.
D. Monitored systems shall maintain a current alarm information file with the alarm company where the alarm is monitored containing the following
minimum information:
1. A recognizable numerical street address;
2. Detailed directions from a major road or landmark;
3. A list of persons authorized to enter the premises and their telephone;
4. Instructions indicating where the alarm is located showing where the shutoff or disarming device is located.
E. The occupant, or owner, if not occupied, of any alarm equipped premises must clearly display on the outside of the premises the name of the alarm
monitoring service and a twenty four (24) hour emergency telephone number answered by a living person.
F. Any alarm monitoring service or premises owner, occupant, or other responsible person serving as representative for any of the foregoing, upon
learning that a false alarm has sounded, shall immediately notify the police department of the false alarm. (Ord. 827 § 2, 1995)
9.44.030: NONCOMPLIANCE AND MULTIPLE FALSE ALARMS; SERVICE FEES, REMEDIES, AND PENALTIES:
A. Failure to comply with the requirements or prohibitions of section 9.44.020 of this chapter shall be subject to the imposition of a service fee upon the
occupant of the affected premises, or the owner, if the premises is not occupied, in accordance with a fee schedule established by resolution of the
city council. Such fee schedule shall reflect the relative level of costs incurred by the city as a result of the building occupant's/owner's
noncompliance. Said fee shall be billed by the city's finance department, and if not paid within thirty (30) days of the occurrence, may be appended to
the municipal utility bill of the premises involved, subject to all collection remedies and terms provided therefor. Such service fee charges may also
be separately collected in a manner deemed appropriate by the finance director.
B. Multiple false alarms, in excess of two (2) from the same location or alarm system within a six (6) month period, continuously and cumulatively until a
six (6) month period free of false alarms has been achieved, shall obligate the occupant/owner to pay a service fee as set forth in a resolution
adopted by the city council which shall become due and payable no later than thirty (30) days after occurrence of the third false alarm in a six (6)
month, or longer, period. Said fee shall be billed by the city's finance department, and if not paid within thirty (30) days, be appended to the municipal
utility bill of the premises involved, subject to all collection remedies and terms provided therefor.
C. The occurrence of more than three (3) instances of the conduct prohibited or omission of that required by section 9.44.020 of this chapter within any
continuous six (6) month period shall constitute a violation of this chapter. The occurrence of more than five (5) accidental or unintentional false
alarms within the six (6) month period (or longer until 6 continuous months are free of false alarms), as described in subsection B of this section,
shall constitute a violation of this chapter. A violation of this chapter shall constitute a misdemeanor, punishable as provided in title 1, chapter 1.24 of
this code. (Ord. 1152 § 11, 2008)
9.44.040: AUTHORITY TO ADMINISTER:
The chief of police shall have the authority to administer the process of receiving alarm reports and responses, the placement of alarm systems, and
other practices necessary to aid in the orderly and safe reporting of emergency circumstances within the city. Such authority shall include the authority to
order the disconnection of alarm systems which fail to meet the standards established by this chapter on a continuing basis. (Ord. 827 § 4, 1995)
9.44.050: NO OBLIGATION CREATED IN POLICE DEPARTMENT:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed or interpreted to create a duty to respond on the part of the police department. The police department may
respond to alarms in accordance with the availability of resources, manpower, and in consideration of other duties. (Ord. 827 § 5, 1995)
9.44.060: GRACE PERIOD REGARDING MULTIPLE FALSE ALARMS:
There shall be a ninety (90) day grace period respecting the accidental false alarm provisions of this chapter beginning at the effective date hereof,
during which time no service fee will be charged to a premises occupant/owner exceeding the limits established by subsection 9.44.030B of this chapter.
Such grace period shall not affect liability for penalties for violation of this chapter. (Ord. 827 § 6, 1995)

Chapter 10.04
UNIFORM TRAFFIC CONTROL CODE

STATE MOTOR VEHICLE LAWS ADOPTED

Chapter 10.12
U-TURNS
10.12.010: RESTRICTIONS:
The drivers of vehicles in the city are prohibited from making reverse or U-turns on any street in the municipality between intersections. U-turns will be
permitted at intersections except where otherwise posted. (Prior code § 10-2-2)
Chapter 10.16
SPEED LIMITS
10.16.010: DESIGNATED:
A. Due to the residential, urban or business character of the neighborhood abutting the streets in residential, business or urban districts, the reasonable
and safe maximum speed limits within the city limits shall be:
1. All streets three (3) lanes in width or less within the city shall bear a maximum speed limit for wheeled vehicles of twenty five (25) miles per hour,
unless posted signage indicates to the contrary.
2. Unless posted signage indicates to the contrary, all four (4) lane or greater streets within the city shall bear a maximum speed limit for wheeled
vehicles of thirty five (35) miles per hour.
B. The speed limits in school zones shall be twenty (20) miles per hour, when children are present.
C. The street superintendent, the city engineer, or their designee, may adopt a temporary speed limit lower than the customary speed limit in a given
area when such speed limit is deemed necessary to cover special conditions arising from construction zones, street maintenance or special events
approved by the city. The temporary speed limit shall be posted in conformance with Idaho Code section 49-209. (Ord. 1020 § 3, 2003: Ord. 840 § 1,
1996: Ord. 697 § 2, 1993)
10.16.020: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any wheeled travel in excess of the speed limits established in this chapter or by signage posted by the city pursuant to determination of the city
engineer, street superintendent, or city council, which signage is authorized, is deemed not reasonable and prudent, and the same is unlawful. Violation
of this chapter shall be subject to punishment as an infraction. The penalty for an infraction violation shall be as determined by order of the Idaho
supreme court, as such is adopted from time to time. (Ord. 1020 § 4, 2003: Ord. 697 § 3, 1993)
Chapter 10.20
PARKING
10.20.010: TEMPORARY PARKING RESTRICTIONS; AUTHORITY OF CHIEF OF POLICE:
The police department is authorized to indicate temporary zones or locations, for a period not to exceed seven (7) consecutive days, where vehicles
shall not be parked when, in the opinion of the chief of police, it is necessary to temporarily prevent the parking of vehicles to avoid public harm or
inconvenience. The chief of police may do so either by placing appropriate signs or placing barricades or officers at such places where parking is to be
restricted. The chief of police is empowered to employ the authority granted by this section to take such actions as may be necessary to prevent parking
on public streets which blocks or otherwise impedes the convenient delivery of mail by the U.S. postal service. It shall be unlawful for any person to park
any vehicle at such time and at such designated places in violation of the restrictions established by the chief of police. The police department is
authorized to remove such illegally parked vehicles and the owner thereof shall pay the cost of such removal and storage. (Ord. 1020 § 5, 2003: Ord.
710 § 1, 1993)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 86/268
10.20.020: PARKING REGULATIONS; GENERALLY:
A. No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or to comply with law or the directions of a
police officer or traffic control device, in any of the following circumstances:
1. At any location where a traffic control device restricting or prohibiting parking has been posted by a department head or his/her designee;
2. On or across a public sidewalk, pedestrian path, bicycle path or similar nonvehicular right of way, or between the curb and sidewalk or within an
area improved on the right of way for stormwater drainage;
3. In front of, or otherwise blocking use of, a public or private driveway or street access from lands adjoining a public street;
4. Within an intersection of public rights of way;
5. On, or impeding use of, or within twenty feet (20') of, a pedestrian crosswalk or the point of intersection of public rights of way measured at the
curb line for streets so developed, provided that this limitation shall not apply to vehicles in public service which may park within six feet (6') of
such points;
6. Alongside or opposite any maintenance or construction operation or obstruction when stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic;
7. On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street;
8. Upon a bridge or other elevated structure upon a street or highway or within a highway tunnel;
9. At any place where official signs prohibit stopping;
10. In an alley so as to hinder or block traffic;
11. In a marked fire lane on the site of any structure open for public access or where access restrictions have been imposed by the fire department.
12. The city of Post Falls is hereby authorized to post and enforce parking regulations in public places. The regulations in this section shall apply in
the incorporated and unincorporated areas of the city.
B. The city council may designate a tow away zone at any location where a traffic control device restricting or prohibiting parking has been posted by
authority of a department head or his/her designee, provided that the tow away warning is posted along with the traffic control device which restricts
or prohibits parking. Whenever any peace officer finds a vehicle in violation of this provision, the officer is authorized to require the driver or other
person in charge of the vehicle to move it, or to remove or cause to be removed to a place of safety any unattended vehicle. The procedures of Idaho
Code, title 49, chapter 18 are hereby adopted concerning disposition of vehicles. (Ord. 1286, 2015)
10.20.030: PARALLEL:
Motor vehicles shall be parked parallel to the curb on all streets and avenues, with the right hand wheels within eighteen inches (18") of the curb. Motor
vehicles shall not be parked within thirty feet (30') of the corner of the curb or edge of road or within fifteen feet (15') of any fire hydrant. It is unlawful for
any person to park a vehicle on any portion of any street where the curb is painted yellow, except as provided herein.
A. Exceptions:
1. On one-way streets, motor vehicles shall be parked parallel to the curb on all streets and avenues with either the right hand wheels or the left hand
wheels within eighteen inches (18") of the curb.
2. Angled parking is allowed at locations where angled parking spaces are designated by the city by the use of pavement markings or in areas where
the designated parking area is designated by a modification of the curb line that provides a recessed parking area.
3. No parking of any type will be allowed when signage is posted prohibiting parking. (Ord. 1154 § 1, 2008)
10.20.040: ALLEY:
No motor vehicle shall be parked in the alleys of the city except for the purpose of loading or unloading, which shall be done as expeditiously as possible
and shall not exceed thirty (30) minutes' elapsed time in any one block unless special permit be obtained from the chief of police. (Prior code § 10-4-3)
10.20.050: TIME LIMITATION:
No vehicle, including major recreational vehicles or equipment, shall be parked continuously at the same location or combination of locations within the
same block on any public street or public alley on any public street or alley in the city for more than twenty four (24) hours. For the purpose of this
chapter, "major recreational vehicles and equipment" are defined as including, but not limited to, boats and boat trailers, pickup campers or coaches
(designed to be mounted on automotive vehicles), motorized dwellings, and tent trailers. (Ord. 1201, 2010)
10.20.060: PRIVATE PROPERTY:
A. It is unlawful for any person to park upon the private property of another without the consent of the owner of such property, and the police department
is authorized to remove the vehicle therefrom and cause the same to be stored, following the procedures under title 49 of the Idaho Code, provided
the owner of the private property has first complained against the owner or operator of such vehicle.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 87/268
B. It is unlawful for any person to park a vehicle in the front yard of a residence that is not an improved driveway. For the purpose of this section, an
improved driveway shall be an off street vehicle access to a parcel of land from a private or public street or alley constructed of compacted gravel,
grass pavers, brick pavers, asphalt or concrete.
C. Automotive vehicles or trailers of any kind or type without current license plates shall not be parked or stored on any residentially zoned property
unless stored in a completely enclosed building or carport. One boat and/or one recreational vehicle without licenses may be stored in the side or
rear yard, but not in any front yard. (Ord. 1201, 2010)
10.20.070: PICK UP AND DELIVERY:
Whenever possible all deliveries and pick ups by motor vehicles or by trucks shall be made from the alleys. (Ord. 1020 § 9, 2003: prior code § 10-4-4)
10.20.080: CITY PARKS; FEES:
A. This section shall be known and cited as the parking fee regulations for designated fee parking areas of the Post Falls city parks.
B. The Post Falls park and recreation department shall have full authority to designate certain parking areas of city parks as fee parking areas.
C. A parking fee shall be collected from the driver of each automobile desiring to park in the designated fee parking area.
Parking fees shall be paid upon entrance to the designated fee parking area.
D. Any person may purchase an annual parking permit from the Post Falls park and recreation department which shall authorize a vehicle with that
sticker firmly attached to its windshield access to the designated fee parking area providing that sufficient parking space is available for that vehicle
at the time of entrance. The amount of the daily parking fee and fee for an annual permit shall be set by resolution of the city council.
E. A person seeking only to launch a boat at the boat launch, and does not park the vehicle or trailer, shall not be required to pay a fee. The vehicle and
boat trailer shall not be left for more than one-half (1/2) hour during the launching process without parking the vehicle and trailer. This provision shall
not apply to towing vehicles with an annual parking permit. (Ord. 1020 § 10, 2003: Ord. 533, 1987: prior code § 10-4-9)
10.20.090: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
It is unlawful for any individual to violate any of the provisions of this chapter. Anyone found violating any provision of this chapter, except section
10.20.060 of this chapter, may be issued a civil citation and shall be assessed a civil penalty as established by resolution of the city council for first
violations. The city citation assessment shall be payable at the city hall, or Post Falls police department, within thirty (30) days from the date of issuance.
If, within the thirty (30) day period following the issuance of a city citation the assessment has not been paid, or if a second or subsequent violation is
committed, a uniform infraction citation may be issued and the violator, if found guilty, will be fined as provided by law. In the alternative to the city
citation process, a peace officer may issue a uniform infraction citation which shall be payable as provided by law. A violation of section 10.20.060 of this
chapter shall be a misdemeanor. (Ord. 1206, 2010)
Chapter 10.24
OPEN CONTAINERS OF ALCOHOL IN VEHICLES
10.24.010: ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR DEFINED:
As used in this chapter, the term "alcoholic liquor" has the following meaning: Any spirits, wine, beer (including 3.2 beer), ale, or other liquid containing
more than one-half (1/2) of one percent (1%) of alcohol by volume which is fit for beverage purposes or is intended for beverage purposes. (Prior code
§ 6-1-49(A))
10.24.020: PROHIBITED:
No person shall have in his or her possession an open or unsealed container containing alcoholic liquor within an area accessible to operators or
passengers of a motor vehicle, including motorcycles, while such vehicle is in motion on any thoroughfare, public street, alley, or public parking lot within
the city, except for passengers in the passenger area of a motor vehicle designed, maintained, or used primarily for the transportation of persons for
compensation, or in the living quarters of a recreational vehicle as defined by title 49 of the Idaho Code. (Ord. 1020 § 11, 2003: prior code § 6-1-49(B))
10.24.030: WARNING ISSUANCE:
(Rep. by Ord. 1020 § 12, 2003)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 88/268
10.24.040: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person operating or in actual physical control of a motor vehicle, as defined by title 49 of the Idaho Code, violating any provision of this chapter shall
be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable as provided in title 1, chapter 1.24 of this code. Other persons violating the provisions of this chapter shall be
guilty of an infraction. (Ord. 1152 § 12, 2008)
Chapter 10.28
PARADES, FUNERAL PROCESSIONS AND TEMPORARY STREET CLOSURE
10.28.010: USE OR CLOSURE OF STREETS AND WAYS FOR PARADE, FUNERAL PROCESSION OR RECREATIONAL
PURPOSE; PERMIT REQUIRED; SOLICITATION OF MOTORISTS PROHIBITED:
A. It is unlawful for any funeral procession, parade containing persons, vehicles or animals, or party or festival to occupy, close, march upon or proceed
along any street except in accordance with a permit issued by the chief of police in compliance with such requirements as set forth herein and in
compliance with other provisions of local, state and federal law.
B. Pursuant to section 9.20.010 of this code, no person shall solicit business or contributions from the occupants of any vehicle. (Ord. 1247, 2013)
10.28.020: PARADE PERMIT; CRITERIA:
The following criteria shall be met before a parade permit may be issued by the community development department:
A. The person seeking the issuance of a parade permit shall have completed an application form to be supplied by the community development
department. The completed application form must be received by the community development department at least thirty five (35) days prior to the
date of the parade. The time frame set forth herein may be waived in the discretion of the community development department upon a finding that
such waiver would not compromise the ability of the city to prepare for the activity for which the permit is requested. Any application that is for the
closure of any street or any portion of a street must include a street closure signage and control plan.
B. The community development department must determine from the information contained in the application or from information developed from other
sources, including the knowledge of community affairs by the police department and street department that:
1. The route, timing and nature of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of traffic contiguous to its route or
elsewhere within the community.
2. The route, timing and nature of the parade will not require more police officers than can reasonably be provided, while still providing normal
protection to the city.
3. The route, timing and nature of the parade will not unduly interfere with the proper fire, ambulance, police or other public services to areas
contiguous to the parade or elsewhere in the community.
4. The parade is not likely to cause injury to persons or property or create disorderly conduct or create a disturbance. If the chief of police is unable to
conclude this, he shall meet and confer with the applicant to determine what steps, if any, the sponsor/applicant could take to avoid disorder or to
minimize the possibility of a public disturbance.
5. The parade is scheduled to move expeditiously along a defined route from its place of origin to its place of termination.
6. The parade is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising products, goods, or private commercial events and is not designed to be held
purely for profit or private promotional considerations.
7. The person seeking the issuance of a parade permit has agreed to furnish qualified road guards as needed to assist the police department or has
provided evidence of contractual arrangement to provide same.
8. The person seeking the issuance of a parade permit has tendered payment of the parade permit fee established by the city council by resolution,
such resolution being hereby authorized. Such fee may be waived by the city council upon a showing that the activity to be conducted is to be
carried out primarily for the general benefit of the community.
9. The street closure signage and control plan is in substantial compliance with the "Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices".
C. In the event the community development department cannot make the findings required by this section, the reasons shall be stated in writing and the
applicant notified that an appeal may be brought before the city council at the next available meeting for which proper notice may be provided. When
requested by an unsuccessful applicant, the city council shall consider the application in light of provisions of this chapter and related provisions of
law and take official action concerning such request as appropriate. (Ord. 1180 § 1, 2009)
10.28.030: FUNERAL PROCESSION PERMIT; CRITERIA:
The following criteria shall be met before a funeral procession permit may be issued by the chief of police:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 89/268
A. The person seeking the issuance of a funeral procession permit shall have completed an application form to be supplied by the police department.
The completed application form must be received at least twenty four (24) hours prior to the date of the funeral procession.
B. The chief of police must find that the funeral procession route and time does not conflict with other special events using the same route, or an
affected route, at the same time. (Ord. 963 § 2, 2000)
10.28.040: PERMIT; TEMPORARY STREET CLOSURE ON REQUEST; CRITERIA:
A. Any person seeking the issuance of a permit to temporarily close all or any portion of a street shall include a street closure signage and control plan
along with the closure application.
B. The following criteria shall be met before a permit to close a section of street for a party, festival or other special event may be issued by the
community development department, subject to conditions of mitigation as deemed appropriate:
1. Finding that the flow of traffic within the community and within the adjacent neighborhood will not be adversely or unnecessarily affected.
2. Finding that the provision of emergency services would not be adversely affected by the temporary closure.
3. Finding that the hours of closure will not unreasonably disrupt the peaceful enjoyment of the use of adjoining lands and buildings.
4. Finding that the organizers of the temporary closure event have made a good faith effort to notify all households adjoining the street section to be
closed and have designed events to minimize impairment of access to adjoining land uses.
5. Finding that the street closure signage and control plan is in substantial compliance with the "Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices". (Ord.
1180 § 2, 2009)
10.28.050: FUNERAL PROCESSION; IDENTIFICATION:
A funeral composed of a procession of vehicles shall be identified as such by such method as may be determined and designated by the chief of police.
(Ord. 963 § 2, 2000)
10.28.060: FUNERAL PROCESSION; DRIVER COMPLIANCE:
Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall follow the lead of the vehicles ahead as closely as may be practical and safe. (Ord. 963 § 2, 2000)
10.28.070: FUNERAL PROCESSION, STREET CLOSURE, OR PARADE; DRIVING THROUGH PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for a driver of a vehicle to drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion and
when such vehicles are conspicuously designated. It is likewise unlawful to drive through or across a parade in progress or through a street which has
been temporarily closed. The foregoing prohibitions shall not apply when authorized by a police officer or other authorized monitor of the street closure,
funeral procession or parade. (Ord. 963 § 2, 2000)
Chapter 10.32
TRUCK TRAFFIC AND PARKING
10.32.010: TITLE OF PROVISIONS:
This chapter shall be known and cited as the TRUCK TRAFFIC AND PARKING CODE. (Prior code § 9-15-1)
10.32.020: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent
with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, words in the singular
number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory.
CITY: The city of Post Falls.
DEVIATING TRUCK: A truck which leaves and departs from a truck route while traveling inside the city or which is otherwise in violation of the
provisions of this chapter.
LOT: A platted parcel of real property or a parcel under single ownership.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind.
TRUCK: Any vehicle designed or operated for the transportation of property, and whose licensed weight exceeds sixteen thousand (16,000) pounds. If
the vehicle in question is a tractor-trailer(s) combination, the definition shall include both tractor and trailer(s).
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 90/268
TRUCK ROUTE: A way over certain streets, over and along which trucks coming into and going out of the city must operate. (Prior code § 9-15-2)
10.32.030: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
All trucks within the city shall be operated only over and along the truck routes and on the other designated streets over which truck travel is permitted.
(Prior code § 9-15-3)
10.32.040: EXCEPTIONS:
This chapter shall not prohibit:
A. Operation On Street Of Destination: The operation of trucks upon any street when necessary to the conduct of business at a destination point,
provided streets upon which such traffic is permitted are used until reaching the intersection nearest the destination point.
B. Emergency Vehicles: The operation of emergency vehicles upon any street in the city.
C. Public Utilities: The operation of trucks owned or operated by the city, public utilities, any contractor or material man, while engaged in the repair,
maintenance or construction of streets, street improvements, or street utilities within the city, or any trucks operated for the purpose of solid waste
collection pursuant to a contract with the city.
D. Detoured Trucks: The operation of trucks upon any officially established detour in any case where such truck could lawfully be operated upon the
street for which such detour is established. (Ord. 1020 § 15, 2003: prior code § 9-15-3(A))
10.32.050: TRUCK ROUTES:
The city engineer is authorized to establish truck routes within the city limits and to designate those routes by the appropriate signage. (Ord. 1020 § 16,
2003: prior code § 9-15-4)
10.32.060: TRUCK ROUTES; OUTSIDE ORIGIN, OUTSIDE DESTINATION:
(Rep. by Ord. 1020 § 17, 2003)
10.32.070: TRUCK ROUTES; OUTSIDE ORIGIN, INSIDE DESTINATION:
(Rep. by Ord. 1020 § 17, 2003)
10.32.080: DESIGNATED STREETS:
(Rep. by Ord. 1020 § 17, 2003)
10.32.090: OUTSIDE ORIGIN; SINGLE DESTINATION POINT:
All trucks entering the city for a destination point in the city shall proceed only over an established truck route and shall deviate only at the intersection
with the street, upon which such traffic is permitted, nearest to the destination point. Upon leaving the destination point, a deviating truck shall return to
the truck route by the shortest permissible route. (Prior code § 9-15-6(A)(1))
10.32.100: OUTSIDE ORIGIN; MULTIPLE DESTINATIONS:
All trucks entering the city for multiple destination points shall proceed only over established truck routes and shall deviate only at the intersection with
the street, upon which such traffic is permitted, nearest to the first destination point. Upon leaving the first destination point a deviating truck shall
proceed to other destination points by the shortest direction and only over streets upon which such traffic is permitted. Upon leaving the last destination
point, a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by the shortest permissible route. (Prior code § 9-15-6(A)(2))
10.32.110: INSIDE ORIGIN; OUTSIDE DESTINATION:
All trucks, on a trip originating in the city, and traveling in the city for a destination point outside the city shall proceed by the shortest direction over
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 91/268
streets on which such traffic is permitted to a truck route. (Prior code § 9-15-6(B)(1))
10.32.120: INSIDE ORIGIN; INSIDE DESTINATION:
All trucks, on a trip originating in the city, and traveling in the city for destination points in the city shall proceed only over streets upon which such traffic
is permitted. (Prior code § 9-15-6(B)(2))
10.32.130: MAP MAINTENANCE:
The city clerk shall keep and maintain accurate maps setting out truck routes and streets upon which truck traffic is permitted; the maps shall be kept on
file in the office of the city clerk and shall be available to the public. (Prior code § 9-15-7(A))
10.32.140: SIGNPOSTING:
(Rep. by Ord. 1020 § 17, 2003)
10.32.150: WEIGH IN:
Any law enforcement officer shall have the authority to require any person driving or in control of any commercial vehicle not proceeding over a truck
route or street over which truck traffic is permitted to proceed to any public or private scale available for the purpose of weighing and determining
whether this chapter has been complied with. (Ord. 1020 § 18, 2003: prior code § 9-15-7(C))
10.32.160: CITY AUTHORITY:
The city engineer, street superintendent and/or the mayor are authorized to have posted seasonal axle weight limitation. (Ord. 1020 § 19, 2003: prior
code § 9-15-8)
10.32.170: PROHIBITIONS:
A. No loaded trucks of any size or weight shall be permitted to use any street, except as provided in section 10.32.050 of this chapter, further providing,
no loaded trucks shall have inside destinations located within residentially zoned districts as defined by this code nor shall loaded trucks be parked
upon any street within the city.
B. No vehicle in excess of sixteen thousand (16,000) pounds licensed vehicular weight shall be allowed to park on any street within the corporate city
limits other than for the purpose of loading or unloading cargo. Commercial and wholesale delivery vehicles will be permitted to make home or retail
delivery to places at any location within the city. No tractor-trailer(s) combination vehicles nor any detached tractor or trailer(s) thereof shall be parked
on any street right of way within the city. Not more than two (2) tractor-trailer combinations, whether attached or detached, may be parked on a
residential lot in a residentially zoned district, provided that parking of said vehicles is accomplished completely off public right of way and entirely on
private property, that the vehicles are unladen; and provided, that the parking thereof is not in violation of any other ordinance of the city.
C. No vehicle with wheels or driving surfaces injurious to pavement shall be operated or permitted upon the public thoroughfares of the city unless the
operator of such vehicle first planks such streets. (Prior code § 9-15-9)
10.32.180: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the traffic or parking provisions set out in this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be
fined not more than the amount provided in title 1, chapter 1.24 of this code. (Ord. 1152 § 13, 2008)
Chapter 10.36
BICYCLES
Article I.
10.36.010: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any person to operate or use a bicycle propelled wholly or in part by muscular power upon any of the public thoroughfares or public
highways of the city, without first obtaining from the police department a license therefor, except when the operator is not a resident of the city and is
traveling through the city from one destination outside of the city limits en route to another destination outside of the city limits or is a participant in an
organized bicycle race or rally. (Ord. 1020 § 20, 2003: prior code § 5-12-1)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 92/268
10.36.020: LICENSE; ISSUANCE; FEE:
The police department is authorized and directed to issue, upon written application, bicycle licenses. The license shall become due on January 1 and
shall be valid until December 31 of said year. The licenses when issued shall entitle the licensee to operate such bicycle for which the license has been
issued, upon all the public thoroughfares of the municipality, exclusive of sidewalks. No fee shall be charged. (Ord. 572 § 1, 1989: prior code § 5-12-2)
10.36.030: SAFETY STANDARDS:
(Rep. by Ord. 1020 § 21, 2003)
10.36.040: STICKER; REQUIRED:
The municipality shall provide each year metallic license stickers and/or seals, together with registration cards and holders therefor, the metallic stickers
and registration cards having numbers stamped thereon in numerical order, beginning with number "1" and indicating the year for which the same are
issued and the words "Post Falls" stamped thereon; such metallic license stickers shall be suitable for attachment upon the frame of the bicycle and it
shall be the duty of the owner, parent or guardian to attach one such metallic license sticker to the frame of each bicycle. It shall be the duty of the police
department to issue a license and collect the fee herein provided for. Such metallic license shall remain attached during the valid existence of such
license. The police department shall also keep a record of the date of issue, to whom issued, and the license number thereof. (Ord. 1020 § 22, 2003:
prior code § 5-12-3)
10.36.050: STICKER; DUPLICATE ISSUANCE:
When a bicycle license sticker has become illegible, lost, stolen or destroyed, upon application of the owner, the police department shall issue another
license sticker for the fee set by resolution of the city council. (Ord. 1020 § 23, 2003: prior code § 5-12-7)
10.36.060: SERIAL NUMBER DESTRUCTION:
It is unlawful for any person to wilfully or maliciously remove, destroy, mutilate or alter the number of any bicycle frame licensed hereunder. It shall also
be unlawful for any person to remove, destroy, mutilate or alter any license sticker, seal or registration card during the time such is operative. Provided,
however, that nothing in this article shall prohibit the police department from stamping numbers of the frames of bicycles on which no serial number can
be found, or on which the number is illegible or insufficient for identification purposes. (Ord. 1020, 2003: prior code § 5-12-6)
10.36.070: SALE; RECORD KEEPING:
(Rep. by Ord. 1020 § 24, 2003)
10.36.080: SALE; RESTRICTIONS:
It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of buying, trading, exchanging secondhand bicycles, to purchase, trade or exchange the same
from or with any person under the age of eighteen (18) years without the written consent of such person's parent or guardian. (Prior code § 5-12-9)
10.36.090: SALE; TITLE TRANSFER:
It shall be the duty of every person who sells or transfers ownership of any bicycle to report such sale or transfer by returning to the police department
the registration card issued to such person as licensee thereof, together with the name and address of the person to whom the bicycle was sold or
transferred, and such report shall be made within five (5) days of the date of the sale or transfer. It shall be the duty of the purchaser of such bicycle to
apply for a transfer of registration therefor within five (5) days of the sale or transfer. (Prior code § 5-12-5)
10.36.100: NONCONFORMANCE; IMPOUNDMENT:
The police department may impound and retain possession of any bicycle operated in violation of any of the provisions of this article, and retain
possession of the same until the violation is corrected. In the event the violation is not corrected and a bicycle is retained in custody more than ninety
(90) days, the vehicle may be sold at public auction following the procedures set out in title 55, chapter 14 Idaho Code. (Ord. 1020 § 25, 2003: prior
code § 5-12-10)
Article II.
10.36.110: EFFECT OF REGULATIONS:
A. It is unlawful for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required herein.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 93/268
B. The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of
this article.
C. These regulations applicable to bicycles shall apply whenever a bicycle is operated upon any public thoroughfare or public path set aside for the
exclusive use of bicycles. (Prior code § 10-1-1)
10.36.120: COMPLIANCE WITH TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICE:
A. Any person operating a bicycle shall obey the instructions of official traffic control signs, signals and other control devices applicable to vehicles
unless otherwise directed by a police officer.
B. Wherever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right, left or U-turn is permitted, it shall be unlawful for any person operating a bicycle to
disobey the direction of any such sign, except where a person dismounts from the bicycle to make such turn in which event such person shall then
obey the regulations applicable to pedestrians. (Prior code § 10-1-2)
10.36.130: RIDING PROVISIONS:
A. A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto.
B. Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride more than two (2) abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use
of such.
C. Whenever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path, except when operating the bicycle
pursuant to a special events permit. (Ord. 1020 § 26, 2003: prior code § 10-1-3)
10.36.140: SPEED LIMIT:
(Rep. by Ord. 1020 § 27, 2003)
10.36.150: EMERGING FROM ALLEY OR DRIVEWAY:
The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall, upon approaching the sidewalk area extending across any alleyway, yield
the right of way to all pedestrians approaching on the sidewalk and upon entering the roadway shall yield the right of way to all vehicles approaching on
the roadway. (Prior code § 10-1-5)
10.36.160: CLINGING TO VEHICLE PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person riding upon any bicycle to attach the same or himself to any vehicle upon any public thoroughfare. (Prior code § 10-1-6)
10.36.170: IMPEDIMENT RESTRICTIONS:
It is unlawful for any person operating a bicycle to carry any package, bundle or article which prevents the rider from keeping at least one hand upon the
handlebars. (Prior code § 10-1-7)
10.36.180: PARKING PROVISIONS:
It is unlawful for any person to park a bicycle in such a manner as to interfere or obstruct pedestrian traffic. (Prior code § 10-1-8)
10.36.190: RIDING ON SIDEWALK:
It is unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within a business district or to ride a bicycle on any sidewalk or roadway on which is
erected by the city a sign prohibiting the riding of bicycles thereon. (Ord. 1020 § 28, 2003: prior code § 10-1-9)
10.36.200: EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS:
A. Every bicycle when in use at nighttime shall be equipped with a lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at least five
hundred feet (500') to the front and a red reflector on the rear of a type which shall be visible from all distances from fifty feet (50') to three hundred
feet (300') to the rear when directly in front of lawful upper beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light visible from a distance
of five hundred feet (500') to the rear may be used in addition to the red reflector.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 94/268
B. Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the operator to make the braked wheel skid on dry, level, clean pavement. (Prior code
§ 10-1-10)
Chapter 10.40
VEHICLES PROHIBITED ON SIDEWALKS
10.40.010: DRIVING OR PARKING ON SIDEWALK PROHIBITED; EXCEPTION:
It is unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to drive within any sidewalk area, bicycle path or other pedestrian path, except at a permanent or temporary
driveway. For the purposes of this section, the sidewalk area shall include the area between the roadway side of the curb and the sidewalk. No vehicle
shall be parked within any sidewalk area except public service vehicles. (Ord. 1020 § 29, 2003: prior code § 10-2-8)
Chapter 10.44
TRAFFIC PENALTIES
10.44.010: DESIGNATED:
Any violation of chapters 10.12, 10.16, 10.28 and 10.40 of this title shall be an infraction punishable by a fine not exceeding one hundred dollars
($100.00). (Ord. 1020 § 30, 2003: Ord. 509 § 1, 1986: prior code § 10-2-10)
Chapter 10.48
SNOW REMOVAL
10.48.010: PLOWING OR DEPOSITING SNOW, DIRT OR DEBRIS ON PUBLIC RIGHT OF WAY PROHIBITED:
A. It is unlawful for any operator of snow removal equipment or the owner of any land upon which snow removal equipment is operated to place or
otherwise permit, sanction, approve or cause the placement of any fallen snow onto public property or rights of way upon its removal from privately
owned lands.
B. Depositing or causing to be deposited dirt or debris within the public rights of way without the permission of the city is declared to be a nuisance and
the responsibility of the person making such deposit to immediately remove the dirt from the right of way. (Ord. 1020 § 31, 2003: Ord. 696 § 1, 1993)
10.48.020: VIOLATION; MISDEMEANOR:
Any violation of the provisions of this chapter shall constitute a misdemeanor. (Ord. 696 § 1, 1993)
Chapter 10.52
MAINTENANCE OF INTERSECTION VISIBILITY
10.52.010: VISIBILITY AT INTERSECTIONS OF PUBLIC ROADS:
At the intersection of any two (2) traveled public rights of way, or the intersection of a public right of way with a private street not otherwise subject to the
nondiscretionary requirements of Idaho Code section 49-221, or its successor, nothing shall be erected, placed, planted or allowed to grow in such a
manner as to materially impede vision for drivers using the adjacent rights of way in accordance with applicable traffic laws. The duty for compliance
with this general requirement shall rest with the property owner or with the occupant/resident of any such premises, as appropriate. Establishment or
maintenance of any such sight obstruction may be deemed a nuisance and, subject to the provisions hereof, may be subject to abatement as provided
by law. (Ord. 1171 § 6, 2009)
10.52.020: HEIGHT REGULATIONS:
Any structure, tree, vegetation, sign or solid, sight obscuring item, which might obscure vision between three feet (3') and ten feet (10') in height and
which is located upon private property within a triangle formed by intersecting right of way lines, or the intersection of right of way lines with the property
or easement lines for private roadways, and having twenty five foot (25') sides adjoining the intersection of two (2) streets, may be subject to the
determination and enforcement authorized by this chapter. The city engineer or the chief of police, or his/her respective delegate, is hereby authorized to
declare the existence of any such sight obstruction or visibility impairment a nuisance and to take such administrative steps as may be appropriate to
eliminate or modify same. (Ord. 1171 § 7, 2009)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 95/268
10.52.030: NONCOMPLIANCE:
If a satisfactory accommodation cannot be made after administrative efforts, the city engineer or chief of police, or respective delegate, may issue an
order to remove any designated sight obstruction, subject to a right of appeal to the city council at the next meeting of the city council at which the matter
can be heard. The city council shall hear from the property owner/occupant/resident and the officer of the city who issued the order to abate, and render
a final decision concerning the matter. If compliance is not forthcoming after appeal, enforcement of compliance with this chapter and abatement of any
nuisance determined to exist may be pursued by appropriate action on behalf of the city in a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 928 § 3, 1999)
Title 11
RESERVED
Title 12
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES
Chapter 12.04
RIGHT OF WAY CONSTRUCTION PERMITS
12.04.010: PERMITS REQUIRED; STREET AND RIGHT OF WAY IMPROVEMENTS:
A. All construction of new street improvements, including, but not limited to, street base preparation, paving, installation of curbs, gutters, sidewalks,
storm water facilities, sanitary sewer facilities, water line construction or replacement of such facilities, or construction, replacement, or capital
maintenance of any public utility or other facilities desiring to make use of the public right of way, including facilities providing electrical, telephone,
natural gas, irrigation water, and cable television service shall require a right of way construction permit issued by the city public works department.
B. Any construction work in the public right of way which will affect the condition of existing public facilities or will result in the construction of facilities
which will be subject to public maintenance shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter.
C. A public facility construction permit shall be required prior to the initiation of construction work on a new subdivision. Said permits may be issued by
the city engineer or his authorized representative after review and approval of plans and specifications, and payment of required fees. No fee shall
be charged for construction undertaken pursuant to direction by the city.
D. No temporary stockpiling, storage of materials, demolition, storage or equipment, or other activities which would obstruct a public right of way shall be
allowed without a permit issued pursuant to this chapter.
E. The public works department is authorized to develop construction and improvement specification for installation in public rights of way within the city.
Said standards shall be presented to the city council for review and shall be effectiveupon passage of a resolution adopting said standards. Such
standards may be changed by subsequent resolution of the city council. (Ord. 706 § 3, 1993)
12.04.020: PERMIT APPLICATION:
Applications for permits required by this chapter shall be made to the city public works department on forms provided for that purpose. No work subject
to the provisions of this chapter shall be initiated until an application has been completed and approved according to the provisions of this chapter. (Ord.
706 § 3, 1993)
12.04.030: APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS:
Permit requests shall include site plans, engineering plans, specifications, and such other information as may be necessary to allow the city engineer to
determine that standards have been complied with. (Ord. 706 § 3, 1993)
12.04.040: PAYMENT OF FEES REQUIRED:
No permit application shall be deemed complete until the fees required for said application have been paid in full. The fees for permit issuance and for
construction inspection oversight are authorized by this chapter. Said fees may be set, and changed from time to time, by resolution of the city council.
(Ord. 706 § 3, 1993)
12.04.050: PERMIT IS BINDING ON APPLICANT:
Any permit required by this chapter shall be binding upon the applicant until all obligations established by the terms of this chapter and by the terms of
the specific permit have been complied with in their entirety. A permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall not be transferable to any other person or
entity. The public works department may require written proof that the person making application is a bona fide representative of the identified permit
applicant. (Ord. 706 § 3, 1993)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 96/268
12.04.060: PERMIT IS REVOCABLE FOR CAUSE:
A. Notwithstanding compliance with the application procedures set forth in this chapter, or with resolutions adopted pursuant to this chapter, any permit
issued pursuant to the authority established by this chapter shall be revocable, for cause, in the sole discretion of the public works department.
Revocation may occur in summary fashion upon the happening of any material noncompliance with permit terms, material noncompliance with terms
of this chapter or standards adopted pursuant to it, or for other such substantial reason as the public works department might determine, including
the submittal of inaccurate ormisleading information on any application.
B. Revocation of any such permit shall require that work cease unless specifically allowed to continue, by written order of the public works department,
in order to eliminate a hazard or to preserve the integrity of work in progress. Issuance of a permit pursuant to this chapter shall not convey any
ongoing right to construct in or occupy any public right of way. The permission to construct authorized by this chapter shall be revocable at will and
without recourse. All such permits are temporary and shall be effective only for the limited time frame authorized in the permit.
C. The city reserves the right to remedy any condition associated with construction in a public right of way which it deems to pose an imminent threat to
the public health, safety and welfare. The costs of said remedial action shall constitute a charge against the permit applicant, which costs shall be
reimbursed to the city prior to restart of construction. (Ord. 706 § 3, 1993)
12.04.070: APPLICATIONS; TIMING:
Applications for permits required by this chapter shall be made in advance of the date upon which work is scheduled to commence. Advance timing shall
be variable depending upon the scope of the work to be completed and the degree of prior review which has been conducted. Review periods may be
waived by the public works department in the event of emergencies. The permit shall provide a time limit within which the work shall be completed. The
permit shall be void if the work is not commenced and completed within the date specified on the permit unless an extension of time, for good cause, is
granted as provided in section 12.16.100 of this title. (Ord. 706 § 3, 1993)
12.04.080: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
Any applicant for a permit authorized by this chapter shall demonstrate that is has general liability insurance in the amount of five hundred thousand
dollars ($500,000.00) which insures said work against damage to public facilities and against damage to the public in general. No permit shall issue
without proof of such insurance. The public works department is authorized to maintain a registration of qualified contractors for purposes of simplifying
administration of this requirement. Any such proof of insurance shall require at least thirty (30) days' advance notice of cancellation or expiration to the
city. (Ord. 706 § 3, 1993)
12.04.090: RESPONSIBILITY FOR CONSTRUCTION OBSERVATION; SUBDIVISION:
Primary responsibility for construction inspection for new subdivisions shall rest with the permittee's licensed professional engineer. The permittee's
engineer shall provide thecity with documentation of compliance with city construction standards and attendant construction observation necessary to
verify compliance, as required by the city engineer. The city retains an absolute right to inspect and to require production of test results to assure
compliance with city standards. If test results are not produced or inspection is impeded, the permit may be revoked in the sole discretion of the public
works department. (Ord. 706 § 3, 1993)
12.04.100: QUALITY CONTROL STANDARDS:
Standards for construction quality control and inspection shall be the latest adopted by resolution of the city council, pursuant to recommendation by the
public works department. (Ord. 706 § 3, 1993)
12.04.110: PENALTY FOR VIOLATION:
Violation of this chapter shall constitute a misdemeanor. This chapter may also be enforced by initiation of civil legal action to compel compliance with
the terms of this chapter or to restrain violation thereof. All costs of civil enforcement shall be borne by the violator. (Ord. 706 § 3, 1993)
Chapter 12.08
CURB AND SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION
Chapter 12.12
DRIVEWAYS AND CURB CUTS
12.12.010: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
APRON: That portion of the driveway approach extending from the gutter flow line to the sidewalk section and lying between the end slopes of the
driveway approach.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 97/268
CURB RETURN: The curved portion of a street curb at street intersections or the curved portion of a curb in the end slopes of a driveway approach.
DRIVEWAY: An area on private property where automobiles and other vehicles are operated or allowed.
DRIVEWAY APPROACH: An area, construction or improvement, between the roadway of a public street and private property intended to provide access
for vehicles from the roadway of a public street to a definite area of the private property, such as a parking area, a driveway, or a door, intended and
used for the ingress and egress of vehicles. The component parts of the driveway approach are termed the apron, the end slopes or the curb return, and
the sidewalk section.
END SLOPES: Those portions of the driveway approach which provide a transition from the normal curb and sidewalk elevations to the grade of the
apron, either by means of a sloping surface or by means of a curb return together with the area between the projected tangents of the curb return.
SIDEWALK SECTION: That portion of the driveway approach lying between the back edge of the sidewalk and the apron plus the end slopes measured
at the front edge of the sidewalk. (Prior code § 9-10-1)
12.12.020: PERMIT; REQUIRED:
No person, firm or corporation shall remove, alter or construct any curb, sidewalk, driveway approach, gutter, pavement or other improvement in any
public street, alley or other property owned by or dedicated to or used by this city and over which it has jurisdiction to regulate the matters covered
hereby, without first obtaining a permit from the city clerk and no permit shall be granted until the applicant shall file with the city works superintendent,
for his approval, two (2) copies of a drawing showing the location, size and type of construction of all such proposed improvements to serve the property
affected. (Prior code § 9-10-2)
12.12.030: PERMIT; APPLICATION; FEE:
Applications for permits to construct such improvements shall be made to the city works superintendent on forms provided for that purpose. Fees for the
issuance of permits provided for in this chapter shall be:
A. For each residential driveway or curb cut, five dollars ($5.00);
B. For each commercial driveway or curb cut, five dollars ($5.00). (Prior code § 9-10-3)
12.12.040: PERMIT; ISSUANCE:
Upon approval by the city works superintendent of the drawing of the proposed improvements, and the receipt of the permit fees as stated in section
12.12.030 of this chapter, the city clerk shall issue a permit for the improvement. (Prior code § 9-10-4)
12.12.050: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
A. No driveway approach shall be permitted to encompass any municipal or public utility facility without the express written consent of the city or the
public utility owning the facility.
B. At street intersections no portion of any driveway approach, including end slopes, shall be permitted closer than two feet (2') to the intersection of the
prolonged property lines and the curb.
C. At street intersections no portion of any driveway approach, including end slopes, shall be permitted closer than two feet (2') to the intersection of the
prolonged back edges of the sidewalks and the curb.
