Chapter 12.40
VALUE OF REAL ESTATE IN LOCAL IMPROVEMENT DISTRICTS
12.40.010: FULL CASH VALUE DEFINED:
By the term "full cash value" is meant the value at which the property would be taken in payment of a just debt from a solvent debtor or the amount the
property would sell for at a voluntary sale made in the ordinary course of business, taking into consideration its earning power when put to the same
uses to which property similarly situated is applied. (Prior code § 9-4-2)
12.40.020: DETERMINATION:
The actual value of the real estate in local improvement district no. 1 and any subsequently formed local improvement districts shall be the full cash
valuation. The board of trustees shall appoint for local improvement district no. 1, and for any subsequently formed local improvement districts, three (3)
disinterested persons who are residents and taxpayers within the city of Post Falls, to establish the full cash value of each lot, block and parcel of land,
or any unplatted area lying within local improvement district no. 1 or any subsequently formed local improvement districts. (Prior code § 9-4-1)
Chapter 12.44
COMMERCIAL USE OF PUBLIC PROPERTY
12.44.010: RESTRICTIONS GENERALLY:
No commercial or business activity of any nature except as hereinafter specifically allowed shall be carried on or conducted on city owned property. For
the purpose of this chapter, city owned property shall include public right of way under the jurisdiction of the city, but shall not include commercial or
business activity that consists of using the public right of way for motor vehicle traffic purposes. (Ord. 1210, 2011)
12.44.020: NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS:
The mayor or his designee are authorized to waive the permit fee for charitable or community nonprofit organizations. (Ord. 1210, 2011)
12.44.030: CONCESSIONS GENERALLY:
The director of the parks and recreation department is authorized to enter into agreements with vendors to operate concessions on city property and to
establish the criteria for such concessions. (Ord. 1210, 2011)
12.44.040: PERMIT REVOCATION:
Concession or commercial activity permits may be revoked at any time by the parks and recreation department or police department upon any one or
more of the following occurrences:
A. Failure to follow hours of operation restrictions;
B. Failure to maintain clean, neat and tidy concession area;
C. Revocation of health department permit;
D. Violation of any state, county or city statute, ordinance or regulation;
E. Failure to maintain insurance as herein provided;
F. Causing damage to city owned property or creating a public safety hazard.
Providing that the concessionaire is first given a notice of violation and intent to revoke warning not less than twenty four (24) hours prior to proposed
revocation and, further providing, concessionaire has failed to cure and remove the violation during the twenty four (24) hour period, except when the
violation is related to damaging city owned property or creating a public safety hazard. If such a violation were to occur, the activity must cease and the
city owned property vacated immediately upon receipt of the notice of violation. (Ord. 1210, 2011)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 112/268
12.44.050: PERMIT; APPEAL:
Concessionaire shall have the right to appeal the permit revocation to the city administrator within ten (10) days of the revocation. If not so appealed, the
revocation remains permanent for the remainder of the season. The decision of the city administrator shall be permanent and binding upon the
concessionaire. Upon revocation, concessionaire shall remove the concession from the property of the city and bear the entire cost thereof. If not so
removed within five (5) days of notice of revocation, the city may remove the concession and recover the costs thereof from concessionaire, including
any court costs and attorney fees incurred in so doing. (Ord. 1210, 2011)
12.44.060: DISPLAY AND PROMOTION LIMITED; AUTHORIZATION REQUIRED:
Commercial displays, promotions, arts and craft displays, exhibits or other commercial activities with items for sale may be permitted in the discretion of
the PRD or PD. Application for commercial display permits must be received a minimum of thirty (30) days before the requested permit date. Permit fees
will be based upon the nature and scope of the activity and shall be set by the PRD or PD with rights to appeal to the city administrator. (Ord. 1210,
2011)
12.44.070: PERMIT; BOND:
The PRD or PD may, by special permit where a commercial activity, in the opinion and discretion of the PRD or PD, will aid in a general community
promotion, grant permits for the operation and carrying on of commercial or semicommercial enterprises on city owned property, under the following
conditions:
A. Liability, Insurance: The person or organization operating such enterprise shall enter into an agreement with the city, holding the city and its elective
and appointive officers and employees harmless from any and all liability for injury to persons or property and agreeing to reimburse the city for any
injury to city property and, to this end, file with the city clerk evidence satisfactory to the legal department of the city a policy of liability insurance in
the minimum amounts of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for injury to property or persons per occurrence, with the city named as an
insured thereon.
B. Bond: Post a bond in the form and amount deemed sufficient by the city administrator and payment of such fees as may be required by the city
administrator. (Ord. 1210, 2011)
Chapter 12.48
PARKS
Article I. Use Restrictions
12.48.010: HOURS:
It is unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle, use any equipment, facilities, accessories, or appliances for camping purposes, sleeping, or
preparing meals, in any public park owned or operated by the city between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M.
Special exceptions to this prohibition in the form of overnight camping permission or meal preparation authorization may be granted by express authority
of the director of parks and recreation when the use or activity is of general community benefit or of particular benefit to the city. Approval of any such
exception shall be evidenced by a permit or letter of authorization to that effect which shall be exhibited to any officer of the city upon request. Appeal of
any denial of such a request may be made to the mayor. (Ord. 868 § 1, 1997: prior code § 9-7-1)
12.48.015: ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES RESTRICTED IN PARKS AND PUBLIC AREAS:
A. Between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. on the succeeding day, it is unlawful for any person to have in his or her
possession open containers or receptacles of beer, intoxicating liquor or wine, or to consume such beverages on the grounds, buildings or
thoroughfares or within a motor vehicle moving or parked within any city park or upon other premises owned or subject to exclusive management by
the city of Post Falls, except as otherwise authorized by a permit issued by the city to dispense and consume alcoholic beverages in designated city
park areas or other designated public places at certain times outside the time limits established hereby. Such permit is granted only so long as the
conduct engaged in at the site, and in the park generally, conforms to standards which do not cause inconvenience to or disturb the peace of others.
The authorization for use of alcohol until the permitted time extends only until or unless revoked by a peace officer or by an employee of the city in
which case such permission shall be deemed terminated immediately and the consumption and possession of alcohol shall be concluded upon order
of city personnel. Consumption, possession of open containers and/or dispensing of alcohol may be further restricted or prohibited in any park or
public place by posting signs providing notice of such restriction. The mayor of the city or his designee(s) shall be authorized to issue the
aforementioned permits or authorizations or to designate areas and times where and when consumption, dispensing or possession of open
containers of alcoholic beverages is prohibited.
B. The city council shall serve to hear appeals from administrative decisions regarding the issuance or denial of permits as authorized by this section or
contesting limitations on hours, possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages established for any park or public area pursuant to this section.
The council may establish fees for such permits by resolution. (Ord. 1175 § 1, 2009)
12.48.020: ANIMALS IN PARKS; EXPRESS PERMISSION REQUIRED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 113/268
Notwithstanding provisions of title 6 of this code, animals may be permitted within public parks owned or operated by the city with express prior
permission of the director of parks and recreation. Any such request must be made in writing setting forth the circumstances and control measures
which will be in force if animals are permitted within a park. The director may decline the request if he believes the public interest would not be served
thereby, or he may authorize the kind, type and number of animals which may be allowed, the control measures which must be employed, and the fees
or deposits which may be required to defray costs which the city might incur by virtue of allowing animals in a park. Approval of any such request shall
be evidenced by a permit or letter of authorization to that effect which shall be exhibited to any officer of the city upon request. Any decision made by the
director in this regard may be appealed to the mayor. (Ord. 868 § 2, 1997)
Article II. Container Restrictions
12.48.030: TITLE OF PROVISIONS:
This article shall be known and may be cited as the CITY SOUTH PARK BEACH CONTAINER RESTRICTIONS ARTICLE. (Prior code § 8-6-1)
12.48.040: DESIGNATED:
It is declared unlawful for any person to carry upon, have in their possession, or cause to be deposited on the designated beach area of the South park,
any glass container, pop top type metal container or the opening tag off of the containers. "Pop top" type metal container shall be defined to include, but
not be limited to, any metal container which has an opening secured by a removable metal tag, the removal of which shall create sharpedges on the
container or on the tag removed. (Prior code § 8-6-2)
12.48.050: AREA:
The beach area shall be designated by appropriate signage, the placement of which shall be under the direction and control of the park and recreation
department, which such designated area may be designated and/or changed from time to time by resolution of the city council as the city council so
deems fit and proper. (Prior code § 8-6-3)
12.48.060: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Violation hereof shall be deemed a misdemeanor. (Prior code § 8-6-4)
Article III. Reserved Areas
12.48.070: DESIGNATED:
There shall be three (3) picnic areas within the Q'emiln Riverside park that will be available for reserving. They shall be known as: a) the picnic shelter
area, b) the gazebo area, and c) the ramp area. There shall be one area within the White Pines park at Spokane and 21st Street. It shall be known as
the south picnic area. (Ord. 593 § 1, 1990)
12.48.080: RESERVATION PROCEDURE:
Any individual or group wishing to reserve one of the picnic areas shall apply to the park department of the city. The application must be approved by the
park department and all fees paid before a reservation permit will be issued for any area. (Ord. 593 § 2, 1990)
12.48.090: FEES AND DEPOSITS:
The city council may, from time to time, enact recreation and park use fees and deposits by resolution. Reservation or park use fees may be waived by
the mayor for charitable or community benefit activities that serve the public interest. The mayor shall report any such waivers to the city council. (Ord.
868 § 3, 1997: Ord. 643 § 1, 1992)
12.48.100: PROHIBITIONS:
It is unlawful for any individual or group to reserve, attempt to reserve, or in any way prevent any other person from using anyarea of the parks unless
such individual or group has first received written permission from the park department to reserve the area. Any individual or group authorized by the
park department to reserve an area shall make the permit available for inspection by any employee of the city upon request. (Ord. 593 § 4, 1990)
Article IV. Parks And Recreation Capital Development Fund
12.48.110: CREATED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 114/268
There is hereby created a parks and recreation capital development fund in the system of funds and accounts maintained by the city treasurer. Said fund
balance shall be maintained separate and apart from the general funds of the city and shall be dedicated solely to the purposes of providing and
enhancing the capital facilities for parks and recreation purposes owned or operated by the city. Said fund shall be authorized to carry an accrued
balance from year to year as such shall be authorized at the time of making the annual city budget. (Ord. 803 § 1, 1995)
12.48.120: FUNDING ESTABLISHED BY APPROPRIATION AND RESOLUTION:
A. During the budget process for each fiscal year, or at such time as the city council deems amendment of the city budget appropriate, the city council
may appropriate amounts from the parks and recreation capital development fund to finance improvements, acquisition, or capital renovation of
parks and recreation facilities.
B. The city council may from time to time, by resolution, approve the charging of fees or designate or dedicate other revenues to said fund. Any revenue
measures so designated shall remain dedicated for the purposes set forth in said resolution or as otherwise determined by formal action of the city
council, unless subsequently repealed by action of the city council. (Ord. 803 § 2, 1995)
12.48.130: FULL APPROPRIATION; CONSULTATION:
Expenditures from the parks and recreation capital fund shall be made in accordance with the annual budget appropriation process of the city after
consultation with the parks and recreation commission. The balance of the fund shall be fully appropriated each calendar year unless the city council
determines otherwise during consideration of the proposed budget. (Ord. 803 § 3, 1995)
Chapter 12.52
CEMETERY
12.52.010: ADMINISTRATION AND CARE:
A. Evergreen cemetery is owned by the city of Post Falls. The parks and recreation director, or the director's designee, shall have the authority to
enforce all regulations adopted with respect to the cemetery and to take such actions as may be necessary, including soliciting the cooperation of
any city or other public official, to maintain order upon the premises of the cemetery and has the authority to expel from the cemetery grounds any
person who violates rules established for the cemetery or who otherwise disturbs the peaceful nature of the cemetery grounds.
B. Records of all lot sales, interments and disinterments, including the lot and block of each interment and ownership thereof and the name will be made
available for public inspection by the city during normal business hours. (Ord. 1066 § 2, 2005)
12.52.020: SALE AND USE OF CEMETERY LOTS:
A. All lots shall be sold and utilized subject to rules and regulations adopted by the city council and in compliance with applicable state and federal laws.
B. The interest conveyed when a lot is sold shall be limited to the right to use the property for the burial of human dead. Only the record owner, or a
person or persons with the written approval of the record owner, may be buried in a lot in the cemetery.
C. The price of individual lots and blocks of lots shall be as established by resolution of the Post Falls city council. All sales of lots shall be by cash,
equivalent negotiable instrument, or by time sale agreement in accordance with terms established by resolution of the city council. In the event of
dishonor of any negotiable instrument or failure to perform the terms of a lot sale agreement, any sales transaction or deed shall be void. No deed for
purchase made pursuant to a time sale agreement shall be issued until the final payment is made.
D. The park and recreation director is authorized to refrain from selling additional lots to any person who is delinquent in theirpayments under a time sale
agreement.
E. Use of any single lot shall be as authorized by duly adopted cemetery regulations.
F. No conveyance of any lot shall be valid unless duly executed by the mayor.
G. A fee to disinurn cremated human remains in an amount set by resolution of the city council shall be paid prior to any disinurnment. (Ord. 1066 § 2,
2005)
12.52.030: APPLICATION OF REGULATIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 115/268
Rules and regulations for the use of the Evergreen cemetery may be amended by the city council. All lots sold in the cemetery and use of the cemetery
shall be subject to the rules and regulations in effect at any given time and shall conform to those rules as made applicable by resolution of the city
council from time to time. (Ord. 1066 § 2, 2005)
12.52.040: WORK IN THE CEMETERY:
No person may do work in the cemetery without first obtaining authorization from the park and recreation director or the director's designee. (Ord. 1066
§ 2, 2005)
12.52.050: REMOVAL OF FLOWERS AND DECORATIONS:
No person, other than a city employee or an agent of the city, may remove flowers or other decorations placed on a gravesite by another person. (Ord.
1066 § 2, 2005)
12.52.060: PENALTY FOR VIOLATION:
The requirements established by this chapter and the regulations established by resolution authorized pursuant to this chapter may be enforced by any
city officer. Violation of the provisions of this chapter or regulations adopted pursuant hereto may be sanctioned in the same manner as authorized by
general provisions of this code, including civil action to compel compliance. Additionally, violations which result in additional costs to the city shall be
subject to reimbursement of all such costs, which costs may be pursued by civil legal action if not paid upon demand. (Ord. 1066 § 2, 2005)
Chapter 12.56
SAFE USE OF WATERWAYS
12.56.010: WATERWAY DEFINED:
"Waterway", for purposes of this chapter, means the Spokane River. (Ord. 576 § 1, 1989)
12.56.020: SWIMMING AND DIVING RESTRICTIONS:
It is unlawful for any person to swim or dive into any waterway within the city except in areas designated and signed as swimming areas, or when such
activity is required in the case of a bona fide emergency situation. (Ord. 576 § 2, 1989)
Chapter 12.60
COMPLIANCE WITH POSTED REGULATIONS IN PUBLIC PLACES
12.60.010: VIOLATION OF POSTED RULES PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to violate posted rules, established by the owner or manager, governing orderly personal conduct on the grounds of any
public school, publicly owned building, public park, beach, picnic grounds, or other facility or lands leased or owned by any public agency, or at any
publicly sponsored assembly, recreational activity, or on the premises of any business or other commercial or not for profit enterprise where the public
has general unrestricted access. To be enforceable pursuant to this code provision the subject rules shall be clearly printed in English and posted in a
conspicuous place or places upon or within the premises affected thereby. Owner posted rules regarding parking of motor vehicles upon privately owned
premises shall not be subject to this code provision. (Ord. 768 § 1, 1994)
12.60.020: PENALTY FOR VIOLATION:
Violation of any provision of this chapter shall be deemed a misdemeanor. An initial violation of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed
three hundred dollars ($300.00). Any subsequent violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be punishable as provided in title 1, chapter 1.24 of this
code. Each separate instance of violation shall constitute a separate offense. Enforcement of the provisions of this chapter may be accomplished by
undertaking civil action in a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 1152 § 17, 2008)
Title 13
PUBLIC SERVICES
Chapter 13.04
MUNICIPAL UTILITY SYSTEM; GENERAL PROVISIONS
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 116/268
13.04.010: ESTABLISHED:
Pursuant to authority granted by the Idaho constitution and by statutes of the state of Idaho, and in order to protect the environment and to advance the
social and economic well being of residents and businesses within the city, the city of Post Falls hereby establishes the Post Falls municipal utility
system. Included within the Post Falls municipal utility system are the water system, water reclamation system, solid waste collection system and street
lighting system operated by the city for the benefit of the city's residents. Such system, and administrative personnel given responsibility for its
operation, shall have the powers and authority designated by this code and as otherwise provided by the constitution and statutes of the state of Idaho.
Policy direction for such system shall come from the mayor and city council of the city. Administrative direction shall be provided by the city administrator
and such other city officers as may be designated by this code or by subsequent resolution of the city council. (Ord. 1251, 2013)
13.04.020: GENERAL POLICY:
A. It is the general policy of the city of Post Falls that the municipal utility system will be funded by charges upon users/beneficiaries of the municipal
utility system. Administrative staff of the city should endeavor to operate the municipal utility system on the basis of capital facilities and user charges
to be paid by those who receive benefits from the operation of the system, in whole or in part. General revenues of the city may be used in
circumstances where general community benefits are provided because of the existence and operation of the municipal utility system. It shall further
be the policy of the city to attempt to accrue and maintain adequate financial reserves to repair and replace capacity provided by municipal utility
system components to serve the best interests of the community in the present and future.
B. With respect to capital facilities needs of municipal utility system components, it shall be the general policy of the city to attempt to finance capital
expansion by a combination of development requirements applicable to new development and redevelopment and payment of capacity replacement
fees by new or expanding system users. All new municipal utility system users will be expected to bear their rough proportionate share of the costs of
any capital improvements necessary to replace the capacity of the services provided or to make other changes which should as a matter of policy be
borne by all system users. Regular operation and maintenance expenses, including those of capital replacement, should be financed by adequate
user charges sufficient to pay current operating expenses and adequate to fund reserved amounts for capital replacement.
C. The water reclamation system is intended to be managed in a unified manner addressing both surface water and sanitary sewage. Both carry the
same potential to deliver nutrients (pollutants) to streams and groundwater. Regulatory standards require the two (2) treatment systems to be
separate, even though they seek to accomplish similar ends. Within this title separate chapters address issues associated with sanitary sewage and
management of surface water. Nonetheless, in matters of regulation and funding mitigation and treatment, sanitary sewage and surface water
treatment should be addressed in a complementary way, mindful in every instance that the goals of managing each are the same.
D. Notwithstanding any provision of this code, the mayor and city council reserve the right to derive municipal utility system revenues in any lawful
manner to meet the needs of residents of the city and to maintain the solvency of the municipal utility system in perpetuity. (Ord. 1255, 2013)
13.04.030: OPERATING RESPONSIBILITY:
The responsibility to operate the municipal utility system shall rest in the offices of the various directors of municipal departments assigned to oversee
each of the utility services, subject to executive direction by the mayor and administrative direction by the city administrator. The assigned department
directors shall have authority to appoint managers within the public utility system which they oversee, subject to administrative oversight by the city
administrator. (Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
13.04.040: FINANCIAL RESPONSIBILITY:
The responsibility to carry out the financial policies of the city regarding the municipal utility system shall rest in the office of the finance director of the
city, subject to executive direction by the mayor and administrative supervision by the city administrator. The finance director shall have authority to
appoint subordinates to carry out the business and accounting duties of the municipal utility system. The finance director shall maintain the necessary
funds and account information, and provide reports, projections and forecasts to the mayor and city council, the city administrator and municipal utility
system operating personnel. (Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
13.04.050: FUNDS AND ACCOUNTS:
It shall be the policy of the city of Post Falls to account for revenues and expenditures for components of the municipal utility system in ways that
maintain the integrity of revenues for the services provided. The finance director of the city is hereby authorized to establish discrete funds for
maintaining the revenues and expenditures of the city's water system, water reclamation system (including sanitary wastewater and surface
wastewater), solid waste collection and disposal system and street lighting system. Further, the finance director is authorized, as appropriate, to
maintain separate accounts for capital and operational needs within each of these fund designations. Accompanying this grant of authority the city
council reserves unto itself the authority to consolidate, separate or create additional funds or accounts by resolution, upon consultation with the city
administrator or finance director. (Ord. 1251, 2013)
13.04.060: AUTHORITY TO SET MUNICIPAL UTILITY RATES; OPERATIONAL AND CAPITAL:
The city council reserves unto itself the authority to establish operational and capital facilities fee rates as necessary to fund operation and development
of the municipal utility system authorized hereby. Such fees shall be based upon the needs of the system and shall be established by resolution adopted
by the city council at a duly noticed public meeting.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 117/268
A. Operation and maintenance fees in the form of periodic charges shall be budgeted for regular operating purposes or may be reserved for capital
replacement of facilities subject to depreciation, operational wear and tear or diminished service capabilities due to the passage of time or
environmental conditions. The city council has the authority to set a minimum rate that will be charged for operation and maintenance even if service
is temporarily discontinued.
B. Capacity replacement fees (previously called capitalization fees) shall generally be onetime charges, subject to subsequent adjustment and
recalculation as appropriate, constituting a contribution to the capital reserve necessary to replace capacity consumed by the addition of new users
to an existing system. Such replacement capacity may take the form of additional capital construction or enhanced efficiency measures designed to
increase capacity in order to provide service to future users. (Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
13.04.070: LOAN OF RESERVE FUNDS:
The municipal utility system shall have authority to loan funds held in reserve as a fund balance (except for reserves otherwise committed by contract or
ordinance) to other city accounts and funds as needs dictate. Any such loans must be approved by a resolution of the city council enacted in a duly
noticed public meeting which properly documents the basis for the loan, the rate of interest which the loan will earn, if any, and the terms and conditions
of repayment of the loan. (Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
Chapter 13.08
MUNICIPAL UTILITY SYSTEM; FINANCIAL ADMINISTRATION AND BILLING
13.08.010: USER ACCOUNTS:
The finance director is hereby authorized to establish municipal utility system user accounts for purposes of collecting and accounting for charges and
revenues associated with availability or use of the municipal utility system. Such user accounts shall consolidate the charges due for all municipal utility
system services provided by the city to a certain physical address within the city or as otherwise provided by resolution of the city council. Failure to pay
the entire bill for utility service at one physical address shall constitute grounds for termination of all terminable municipal utility services to the physical
address. The finance director is authorized to limit billing for nonresidential customers to one bill for each water meter, regardless of the number of
tenants in the property. (Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
13.08.020: BILLING SYSTEM; AGREEMENTS MAY BE REQUIRED:
Upon a request to receive services provided by the municipal utility system, the finance director is hereby authorized to establish account procedures to
ensure proper provision of services and payment therefor. Such procedures may include the requirement that the customer/owner execute a written
agreement regarding the services to be provided. Such requirements will be invoked as necessary to comply with provisions of this code and other
provisions of law and to assure that the municipal utility system will be solvent and capable of meeting the needs of the community. Service
requirements may include the payment of a minimum monthly charge necessary to have services available to the property, either to supply the direct
needs of the user or to serve the lands of the user in the context of maintaining the public health, safety and general welfare. Additionally, in order to
secure payment, the finance director may require a deposit from the owner and/or a cosignature from the owner of the property served. (Ord. 1029 § 2,
2003)
13.08.030: PAYMENT FOR SERVICE PROVIDED; OWNER RESPONSIBLE:
A. The city supplies the municipal utility system services itprovides to a specific physical address even though the facilities providing such service may
not be located directly thereon or immediately adjacent thereto. The owner of the property served shall be responsible for payment for the services
provided or available to the owner's property. Any accounts that are currently in the name of the tenant or property management company pursuant
to a letter of agreement and the account balance is current will be allowed to remain in the name of the tenant or property management company
until such time as either the property ownership changes, the tenant changes or the account is delinquent.
B. For nonresidential accounts, the finance director is authorized to establish deposit requirements in whatever amount may be deemed reasonably
necessary to assure payment of the utility charges. The finance director may waive, in writing, the requirement for a deposit as a guarantee. At any
time the finance director may give notice to the property owner that the guarantee requirements of this code have been reinstated if a guarantee was
previously waived. The city administrator and finance director are authorized to take such steps as may be necessary to implement the provisions of
this section. (Ord. 1125 § 1, 2007: Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
13.08.040: NONPAYMENT OF USER FEES AND TESTING FEES AND CHARGES; DISCONNECTION OR DISCONTINUANCE:
A. Failure of the owner of property receiving municipal utility service to pay for services in accordance with this chapter and resolutions adopted
pursuant hereto shall result in termination of municipal utility service to the physical address for which services have been made available or
provided. In addition to temporary disconnection of terminable municipal utility services, the finance director may initiate collection procedures or
legal action in the civil courts to discontinue service or facilitate collection of amounts due and owing for municipal utility services. City staff may take
the necessary administrative steps to implement the provisions of this section, including imposing a fee set by resolution of the city council to
reactivate services.
B. Any request by the owner of the property to have the water service temporarily terminated for the purpose of nonemergency maintenance or repairs
shall be made no less than three (3) working days prior to the termination of water service in order to allow the city to give forty eight (48) hours'
notice to the tenant of the property or property management company. The request must be in writing and state the purpose for the temporary
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 118/268
termination. The property owner shall pay a fee set by resolution of the city council for the temporary termination and reactivation of the water
service.
C. Payment of the user fees with an insufficient funds check shall be considered nonpayment and, in addition to any other remedies allowed by law,
shall result in immediate termination of municipal utility services. (Ord. 1125 § 2, 2007: Ord. 1029 § 2,2003)
13.08.050: WILL-PAY AGREEMENTS AUTHORIZED:
The finance director is authorized to enter into will-pay agreements with users of municipal utility system services that have become delinquent in
payment of their user fees as required by this title and resolutions adopted pursuant hereto. The finance director is authorized to make business
judgments about the advisability of such agreements. The city council may by resolution set limitations upon the amount of delinquent payments for
which a will-pay agreement may be authorized. The finance director is authorized to have the water service terminated without notice to the customer for
failure to comply with the will-pay agreement. (Ord. 1125 § 3, 2007: Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
Chapter 13.12
WATER SYSTEM
13.12.010: USER CHARGES:
A water service charge in an amount to be determined by resolution of the city council shall be paid for every service or connection to the Post Falls
water system. The resolution may include the establishment of a base rate which shall be a minimum charge to be paid by all users. (Ord. 1029 § 2,
2003)
13.12.020: PAYMENT OF CAPACITY REPLACEMENT FEES; REQUIRED FOR CONNECTION TO MUNICIPAL SYSTEM:
Every owner of property desiring to receive municipal water service, including fire line connections for building sprinkler systems, shall pay a capacity
replacement fee prior to being allowed to connect to the system. No building permit shall be issued until the capacity replacement fee has been paid.
The capacity replacement fee may be set by resolution. (Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
13.12.030: IRRIGATION AND OUTSIDE WATERING:
The use of city water for outside watering and irrigation is prohibited from the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) noon to six o'clock (6:00) P.M., except when
an irrigation system is being operated temporarily for repair or maintenance purposes only. The mayor or his designee is authorized to declare a water
shortage/emergency when the circumstances and weather support the potential for water shortage/emergency. Upon making the declaration of a
shortage or emergency, the mayor or his designee has the authority to additionally restrict, in any manner deemed appropriate, the use of water from the
city's water system for irrigation and outside watering. Such restrictions may include limitations upon the hours, type and location of water usage or may
allow disconnection of users who fail to comply with restrictions. (Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
13.12.040: CONNECTION:
A. No person shall make a connection to the city's water system or otherwise modify or tamper with any part of the public water supply system without
first making application to the city and obtaining written consent from the city. The application shall be on a form provided by the city and must have
all sections completed prior to submission to the city. The application shall state fully and truthfully all purposes for which the water is to be used.
B. Connection to the city water service constitutes an authorization for city personnel to enter upon private property at reasonable times and places for
the purpose of reading water meters and with reasonable notice for the purpose of repairing, inspecting, recalibrating, replacing or removing water
meters which may be located thereon, or for terminating water service.
C. No person shall make a reconnection to the city's water system after the service has been terminated by the city. Any such reconnection must be
done by the city. (Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
13.12.050: CONSTRUCTION OF MUNICIPAL WATER SYSTEM:
A. It is unlawful for any person to construct or extend the city water system within the jurisdiction of the city without first having made formal application
to the city and having received written approval and having complied with all regulations of the city and regulatory agencies. Plans for construction of
the water system components shall be submitted to the city along with an application for service for the city's review and approval. A plan review and
inspection fee in an amount to be set by resolution may be assessed for the review and inspection.
B. Developers of land or property owners may be required to furnish, at no cost to the city, suitable right of way and/or easements for construction,
operation and maintenance of new, existing or future water lines.
C. The city may require city approved full or part time inspection of any water system construction and/or may require a developer to expose any section
of water line to check compliance with applicable standards. The cost of such inspection and/or excavation shall be at the expense of the developer.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 119/268
D. All construction must be in compliance with the applicable city ordinances and standards (whether adopted by ordinance or resolution or specified by
the city engineer), and state and federal regulations, including the requirement to obtain the necessary permits and to pay the permit fees prior to
commencement of construction. The plans shall be designed by a professional engineer (engineer of record) licensed in the state of Idaho.
E. Prior to the city accepting dedication of any system components, the developer shall provide to the city the following:
1. Certification by the engineer of record that the system was constructed in accordance with the plans and specifications.
2. Copies of all field tests and inspection notes.
3. "As built" drawings of the system components acceptable to the city engineer.
4. Acceptance by any required outside agencies.
5. Any required easements or rights of way for the city's continued operation of the system.
6. Assurance and proof that no liens or encumbrances exist against installed system components.
F. No building permits will be issued for new development connecting to new water lines until the ownership of the sewer lines is dedicated to the city
free and clear of all liens and encumbrances and accepted by the city or as otherwise provided by city ordinance to guarantee construction. (Ord.
1029 § 2, 2003)
13.12.060: USE; CONTAMINATION:
A. No person shall use water from the city water system for any purpose other than that which is approved by the city nor shall any person obtaining
approval from the city for water service supply water to other persons. Each residence or premises shall be connected to a separate private service
with an accessible shutoff installed on each service connection to the public supply system.
B. No person shall permit water to be wasted. All outlets must be kept closed except during the time which water is being drawn for necessary use.
C. Owners of property connected to the city water system shall be responsible to keep the faucets, water closets and other fixtures in good repair and
free from leaks. The city has the authority to terminate water service to an owner's property for failure to repair any such leaks within seventy two
(72) hours notice from the city to do so. In the case of an emergency when a leak involves a substantial volume of water, the city has the authority to
enter the property without notice and terminate the water service immediately.
D. No person shall contaminate or befoul any reservoir, stream or watershed, spring or other source from which the supply of water for the city water
system is obtained, nor any pipe, fountain or any other device forming a part of the city water system. (Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
13.12.070: CROSS CONNECTIONS PROHIBITED:
Except as provided in this section, all cross connections, whether or not they are controlled by automatic devices such as check valves or by hand
operated mechanisms such as gate valves or stopcocks, are prohibited.
A. Cross connection shall include, but is not limited to:
1. Water to water and water to air heat exchangers;
2. Bypass arrangements, jumper connections, removable sections, swivel or change over devices;
3. Any other connection where the public water system is connected, directly or indirectly, to any other system which may be capable of imparting
contamination to the public water system; or
4. As provided in any state of Idaho regulations relating to public water systems. (Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
13.12.080: BACKFLOW PREVENTION ASSEMBLY; REQUIREMENTS:
A backflow prevention assembly is required to be installed when the city determines that such an assembly is necessary due to the nature and the
extent of the activity on the premises to prevent cross connection, or when required by state of Idaho regulations relating to public water systems.
A. All backflow prevention assemblies shall be of a type included on the University Of Southern California Foundation For Cross Connection Control And
Hydraulic Research "List Of Approved Assemblies" and approved by the city of Post Falls.
B. Each backflow prevention assembly shall be tested by a tester currently licensed by the Idaho bureau of occupational licenses and registered with the
city of Post Falls water division. In addition to annual field testing, backflow prevention assemblies shall be field tested upon installation and
whenever an assembly is relocated, repaired, or has been taken out of service and returned to service or to ensure that it functions properly. The
tester shall attach a tag stating the tester's name and date of satisfactory test to the assembly.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 120/268
C. A licensed backflow assembly tester shall be responsible for performing accurate field tests and making complete reports of such field tests to the
consumer/assembly owner and the city of Post Falls water division on a form approved by the city of Post Falls. Should the assembly pass according
to the test protocol, the tester shall provide a copy of the backflow assembly test report to the city of Post Falls water division within ten (10) days of
the date of satisfactory test. Any backflow prevention assembly left in a failed (nonpassing) condition creating a potential threat to the public potable
water supply must be reported to the city of Post Falls water division within twenty four (24) hours.
D. A permit shall be obtained prior to the installation of a backflow prevention assembly. The permit fee shall be established by resolution.
E. All commercial/industrial class accounts with backflow prevention assemblies on site shall comply with the annual backflow assembly test
requirements between January 1 and May 15 of each calendar year.
F. All residential class accounts with backflow prevention assemblies on site shall comply with the annual backflow prevention assembly test
requirements within thirty (30) days of the date the irrigation system is recharged (turned on), and prior to June 15 of each calendar year.
G. Any account which fails to comply with section 13.12.070 of this chapter and this section relating to cross connections and the other requirements of
this section will be subject to shutoff. Any account which is subject to shutoff shall be subject to placement of a hang tag delivered to the premises
where service is provided. When noncompliance proceeds to the hang tag stage, the customer shall be responsible for a hang tag fee in an amount
set by resolution of the city council, which will constitute a service charge for collection expenses. If compliance is made after the hang tag has been
placed, the hang tag fee shall be paid in addition to all current and past due water service charges, plus interest, to avoid shutoff of water service to
premises. Additionally, a fee will be charged in an amount to be set by resolution of the city council to restore water to any service which has actually
been shut off (disconnected) due to noncompliance. (Ord. 1233, 2012)
13.12.090: REINJECTION; PROHIBITED:
Any reinjection of water by individual, commercial or industrial users to the public water system is prohibited. (Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
13.12.100: EXTENSION OF WATER LINES:
Every property owner requesting an extension of the water line from the line existing at the time of the request, shall extend the exiting line from the
existing line to the owner's farthest property line at the owner's expense, unless otherwise approved by the city engineer or the property owner must pay
to the treasurer the entire cost of extending the line from the existing line to the property owner's farthest property line at such cost per foot as may be
estimated by the city engineer. Such payment allowance may also require that the property owner grant an easement or other right of way. (Ord. 1029
§ 2, 2003)
13.12.110: METERS:
A. It is unlawful for any person to construct or place upon or about any water meter or meter box any barrier, building, vehicle or other object so as to
conceal, obscure or cover, or in any other manner prevent free access to a water meter or meter box; or in any other manner to hinder, delay or
obstruct city personnel from reading or servicing a water meter.
B. Failure of the owner or occupant to remove any prohibited obstruction after notice being sent by the city to do so, constitutes authorization for the city
to enter upon the private property to remove such obstruction and to charge the cost of that removal to owner and occupant of the property to be
paid along with other water charges and/or to terminate service to the affected address, as deemed appropriate in the sole discretion of the city.
(Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
13.12.120: WATER SYSTEM EQUIPMENT; MAINTENANCE:
The property owner is responsible for the maintenance of the service line from the meter box/curb box to the premises. (Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
13.12.130: FIRE HYDRANTS:
A. It is unlawful for any person, other than a fireman in the performance of his duty, to open or in any way to tamper with any fire hydrant connected with
the water system, unless written permission first is obtained from the city's system operator.
B. It is unlawful for any person to place upon or about any water gate valve connected with the water system any material substance whatsoever that
will prevent access to such fire hydrant or gate and no vehicle shall be allowed to stand within fifteen feet (15') of any such hydrant.
C. The use of private hose in time of or during an alarm of fire for any purpose other than protection of property is prohibited. (Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
13.12.140: TERMINATION OF SERVICE:
A customer's service may be discontinued for nonpayment of user fee or noncompliance with any provisions of this chapter. If requested in writing, the
customer is entitled to a hearing before the mayor prior to the service being discontinued, except in the instance of an emergency. The written request
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 121/268
for such hearing must be received by the city clerk no later than ten (10) days after notice is mailed to the customer or is delivered to the premises that
the service will be discontinued. (Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
Chapter 13.16
SEWER SYSTEM
13.16.010: CONNECTION TO SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM:
A. All newly constructed or established residential, commercial, public or industrial development, except for that which is not required to have a
permanent water connection, shall connect to the sanitary sewer at the time of the new construction or prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy
for expansion of an existing structure in an amount equal to twenty five percent (25%) or more of the existing floor space. All existing developed land
uses which lawfully use permitted and functioning septic systems at the time of annexation into the city may continue such use until such septic
system fails or until it is determined by the city or health officials that retention of septic facilities poses a material threat to environmental resources,
unduly hinders extension of sewerage service to unserved lands which require community sewer service to develop in accordance with the city's
comprehensive plan or until sewer service is made available to the property through an LID or by other means.
B. Upon occurrence of any failure of any existing septic tank or drainfield the property should immediately be connected to any available sewer line, or if
no sewer line is available, repair and replacement shall be accomplished in accordance with health district standards. It is the policy of the city to
require or encourage extension of public sewers to serve areas where septic tanks or drainfields fail or where porous/gravelly soils fail to effectively
treat discharged wastewater on site. The provisions of this section shall not constitute justification to establish any new land use without extending
sewer lines to provide service thereto, even if wastewater treatment capacity is temporarily in short supply.
C. Water quality protection provided by the city addresses not only sanitary sewer needs but also surface water practices as well. Surface water
management by the city is for the benefit of owners of developed and undeveloped lands within the city limits in fulfilling its role of protecting
groundwater and surface waters from receiving nutrients of concern. Surface water management facilities constitute an integral part of the water
reclamation services provided by the city, even if land use of a site does not include development that is connected to the sanitary sewer system.
(Ord. 1251, 2013)
13.16.020: USER CHARGES:
A water reclamation service charge in an amount to be determined by resolution of the city council shall be paid for every service or connection to the
sanitary sewer system and for every developed property that may contribute to surface water flows within the city. User charges shall be based upon
standards of system use assigned to the type of use hooked to the sanitary sewer service and roughly proportional to the wastewater produced by the
user plus the relative cost of providing surface water management by the city. User charges are the user's equitable share of the costs of the general
operating costs of the water reclamation system. No charge shall be less than that for a service unit minimum (SUM).
A. A service unit minimum shall constitute all monthly sanitary sewer flows from a single-family residence. Sanitary sewer use for commercial or
industrial users may also, at the city's sole discretion, be calculated in thousands of gallons per month equivalent to an average flow from a singlefamily
residence, as stated in an adopted rate resolution or as determined by dividing the total biochemical oxygen demand or suspended solids
discharged by thirty four hundredths (0.34) pound of biochemical oxygen demand or suspended solids (SS) per day. A fixed residential water
reclamation charge may be established by resolution based upon typical use of the sanitary and surface water reclamation system, with exceptions
considered only when data demonstrate that production of sanitary or surface wastewater significantly exceeds the norm. The city council may also
establish residential water reclamation rates based in large part upon metered consumption of water if it does so by resolution.
B. For metered nonresidential users (i.e., water or sewage metered), the monthly water reclamation service charge shall be based upon the gallons of
water used or sewage discharged as measured by the water or sewage meter reading plus a proportionally determined surface water management
charge based upon factors related to the scope of surface water management. Sewer charges are based upon the water measurement and the
water flow through the irrigation meter will not be included in the calculation for the monthly sewer charge. The property owner shall install a separate
irrigation meter for all new construction, and modifications to existing structures that would require site plan review pursuant to section 18.20.130 of
this code, in order for the city to be able to separate irrigation water use from other water uses.
C. For nonmetered users, or metered water users where the water reading is not representative of the true sewage flow, the monthly sanitary use
charges may be calculated based upon other verifiable evidence reliably demonstrating actual wastewater system use, but in no instance shall such
charge be less than the service unit minimum. Changes to the monthly charge based upon an adjustment of the actual sewer discharge rate may
become effective upon the adjustment and shall not be retroactive.
D. Any nonresidential user that discharges commercial or industrial wastes or that produces a flow, biochemical oxygen demand or suspended solids
loading in excess of the standards set in subsection A of this section, shall have water reclamation charges established by the city after consideration
of relevant data, the cost of such evaluation to be borne by the discharger. No quality discounts shall be allowed and the city may assess a
surcharge on waste flow with biochemical oxygen demand or suspended solids concentrations above two hundred fifty milligrams per liter (250 mg/l)
until adequate pretreatment is achieved. (Ord. 1256, 2013)
13.16.030: PAYMENT:
Where there is joint billing of sanitation charges, streetlight charges, water charges and/or water reclamation system charges, payment of part of the
billing shall not be considered as payment in full, and if not paid in full, the water department may discontinue water and/or water reclamation service
until all charges are paid in full. If a site is not connected to public water or sanitary sewer systems, building permits for that property may be withheld by
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 122/268
the city and a notice to title recorded indicating that status until such time as the site is connected and all required capacity replacement fees are paid.
(Ord. 1251, 2013)
13.16.040: CAPACITY REPLACEMENT FEES; REQUIRED FOR CONNECTION TO MUNICIPAL SYSTEM:
Every owner of property desiring to receive municipal sanitary sewer service shall pay a capacity replacement fee prior to being allowed to connect to
the system. The capacity replacement fee is the owner's share of the replacement cost of the system that his use will displace. The capacity
replacement fee may be set by resolution and in no case shall be less than that for the service unit minimum. When the initial capacity replacement fee
has been underestimated by virtue of underestimating water use or wastewater flows, or has been overestimated at the time of building permit issuance
or use approval and the estimated level of use has not been reached at least three (3) years after the fee has been calculated or the use of the property
has changed, the city may charge the user an additional capacity replacement fee or reduce the capacity replacement fee amount for demonstrated
usage of the system that differs from that estimated at the time of connection or change of use. This adjusted fee amount may be added to or deducted
proportionately from the user's monthly sewer bill until paid as a sewer surcharge or credit for a period not to exceed one year. Extended surcharge
payment periods not to exceed five (5) years may be granted with city council approval. Increased flows beyond the estimates calculated at the time of
building permit or establishment of use shall perpetually serve as a basis for future capacity replacement fee responsibility with adjustments made no
more frequently than annually.
A. Residential Uses: For residential uses, any residence shall be calculated as a service unit minimum for water reclamation purposes unless evidence
demonstrates substantially greater flows.
B. Nonresidential Uses: For nonresidential uses, sewer flow measured or estimated for the highest one month or thirty (30) day period during a year
shall be the basis for calculating the user fee and the capacity replacement fee amount for a user. Annual adjustments may be made in accordance
with subsequent increases in flow. (Ord. 1251, 2013)
13.16.050: BUILDING PERMITS:
No building permit will be issued until the estimated capacity replacement fee has been paid. (Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
13.16.060: RATHDRUM SYSTEM:
Sewer services to the city of Rathdrum shall be governed by the agreement between the city of Post Falls and the city of Rathdrum dated January 9,
1996, and any subsequent modifications to that agreement. (Ord. 1029 § 2, 2003)
13.16.070: CONSTRUCTION OF SEWER SYSTEM:
A. It is unlawful for any person to construct a community sanitary sewer system component or surface water collection or retention facility within the
jurisdiction of the city without first having made formal application to the city and receiving written approval and having complied with all regulations
of the city and applicable regulatory agencies. Plans for construction of any water reclamation system component shall first be submitted to the city
along with the application for service for the city's review and approval. A plan review and inspection fee in an amount to be set by resolution shall be
assessed for the review and inspection.
B. Developers of land or property owners are required to furnish, at no cost to the city, suitable right of way and/or easements for construction, operation
and maintenance of new, existing or future sewer lines and surface water management facilities.
C. The city may require city approved full or part time inspection of any related construction and/or may require a developer to expose any section of
sanitary sewer or any facet of a surface water facility to monitor compliance with applicable standards. The cost of such inspection and/or excavation
shall be at the expense of the developer.
D. All construction must be in compliance with the applicable city ordinances and standards, and state and federal regulations, including the requirement
to obtain the necessary permits and to pay the permit fees prior to commencement of construction. The plans shall be designed by a professional
engineer (engineer of record) licensed in the state of Idaho.
E. Prior to the city accepting the system, the developer shall provide to the city the following:
1. Certification from the engineer of record that the system was constructed in accordance with the approved plans and specifications and city
minimum quality control standards.
2. Copies of all field tests and inspection notes.
3. "As built" drawings of the system to current city standards.
4. A copy of the video of the interior of the lines that has been reviewed and approved by the engineer of record and the city.
5. Any additional items identified within a construction improvement agreement.
6. Acceptance by any required outside agencies.
7. Any required easements or rights of way for the city's continued operation of the system components.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=350 123/268
8. A warranty and maintenance bond covering the design, construction materials, and workmanship must be provided for a period of two (2) years
from the date of acceptance for maintenance by the city. The surety amount shall be a percentage of the approved construction cost estimate as
set forth in the city's subdivision regulations.
F. No building permits will be issued for new development connecting to new sewerage systems until the ownership of the sewer lines is dedicated to the
city free and clear of all liens and encumbrances and accepted for public use by the city, unless surety is otherwise committed to assure completion
pursuant to provisions of this code. No certificate of occupancy shall be issued for surety backed connections until the sanitary sewer facility has
been inspected and finally accepted for public use. (Ord. 1251, 2013)
